userID:
571765
Display Name:
LYNLOR
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
57
favoritesCount:
111
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are PHENOMENAL biscuits.  I can literally have them on the table in 20 minutes, start to finish.  The only change I make is to use fresh buttermilk, but it isn't a necessary change -- just a really GOOD one. :)  I toss the dry ingredients, cut in a non-hydrogenated palm shortening, then toss the mixture with a fork as I add the buttermilk.  I stop with the milk while it is still pretty crumbly, but moist, dump it all out onto the counter top, then press it together just until all the little stray crumbles have come mostly together.  Dust it with flour, roll it out to about 3/4 inch thick.  I don't bother with a biscuit cutter, but cut it roughly with a large knife into 9-12 (2 inch) squares.  Usually I brush the tops with cream before baking.  These are SO insanely easy, and really, REALLY good.  They literally flake into the same beautiful layers you'd get at KFC...I know, not high class food, but honestly...who doesn't like KFC biscuits?

text:
I really like this recipe. It is my main biscuit recipe I use now. The biscuits are pretty quick to make and rise up nicely. But, do not over work the dough, as with any biscuit recipe to keep the biscuits soft. I just made some this weekend. And, also remember to check the expiration date on your baking powder if you do not use it that much. The fresher the more these biscuits will rise up nice and soft. I like to eat mine with butter, jelly, or honey butter. Yum!

text:
I've made these twice now, following the recipe exactly both times.  The first time, I ended up  making smaller biscuits because when I rolled the dough out to 1" thick, it only made 6 small ones.  I ended up putting them on a cookie sheet and covering them with a towel, and I didn't get to bake them for two days, but my family said they were the best biscuits I have ever made (and I've made a lot of biscuits!)  The second time I made them, I doubled the recipe and put them in the oven right away.  They tasted the same - amazing!  This is a five star keeper for its simplicity and because you can make them ahead of time and they still turn out great.

text:
Very good, basic recipe. Followed the directions for the dough, only adding as much milk as needed, and ended up not needing all the milk. I rolled them a little thinner then directed, folding the dough over a few times and rolling out again instead of kneading, and to make layers, and made smaller biscuits (about 1&1/2 inches across) out of it, baked them about 10 min. at 410 instead of 425 degrees. Used them with a sausage gravy and the only reason there's one biscuit left over is everyone is too full to eat it!

Display Name:
Kata

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/346811.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a good, quick substitute to delicious, but time-consuming Hungarian yeast biscuits. After reading the reviews I knew these would turn out good, but didn't expect the amazing end result I got.  I didn't add sugar as I don't like the sweetness in savory biscuits. I used goose fat leftover from a roast instead of shortening, which gave the dough a rich flavour (typical Hungarian substitution). Also, I love the taste of whole wheat flour, so added some instead of white (a third). I'm glad I added the milk gradually cause I only needed a bit more than 2/3 cup. I didn't do as much kneading as originally written, even so the dough quickly formed into a smooth ball. This recipe is a definate keeper - really versatile and easy to make! Can't wait to try it with different herbs, cheese or butter instead of fat. Thanks for this super basic recipe!

text:
Great biscuit and so easy! I soured my milk before using it (1 Tbsp. vinegar added to 1 c. milk, let sit for 5 minutes before using). This made 9 biscuits for me. My hubby said they needed more salt. I try and not use it where I can get away with it because it's not good for you. I would recommend NOT kneading the dough hardly at all. That way they're nice and light textured. Keeping this recipe!! Thanks Mr. Pickett!

text:
My kids inhaled these biscuits.  Truly fluffy (which we love) and not dense like the traditional Southern biscuits we eat.  I used butter instead of shortening (an ingredient I don't use) and didn't have any problems.  I also followed the recommendation of other reviewers and used my food processor, which made it easy.  I will make these again, but I will add a little more salt and maybe even an extra tbp of sugar.  My husband and I thought they needed more flavor which is why I gave the recipe 4 stars instead of 5.

text:
This pretty well my recipe - BUT - NO WAY should these be kneaded so much! Just tuen the dough onto lightly floured surface, pat into cohesive round & press out to size needed, then cut with sharp cutter. Incidentally, for a better rise, after cutting, turn reach round over & place on baking sheet. Den7

text:
OK I tried these a couple of weeks ago and got hockey pucks.  Followed the recipe, used butter and thought I was gonna chip a tooth on these petrified Big Daddy's...whoa!  Then I tried them again with fresh baking powder (I thought maybe mine was dead) and boy did they work that time!!  Whooooeeeeee.  So make sure your baking powder is fresh.   BTW I rolled mine out about 1/2 to 3/4" and next time will do the 'Full Monti" and go with an inch thick.  They rose perfectly but that extra little bit will put them over the top.  Thanks John, your old Motor pal, Vinny.

text:
Fluffy, easy, delicious. Two things to note: keep your butter cold, and only add as much milk as you need to bring your dough together. I added almost the entire cup and my dough ended up a little too moist. I got it back to a workable moisture level but it would have been easier if I had just added the milk more slowly from the beginning. Also, I had a little bit of dough left over so I made a mini batch of monkey bread. It was FANTASTIC with this recipe! I'm going to make this again tomorrow and perhaps add a splash of vanilla to the dough for a new batch of monkey bread. Yum!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were quick and easy. I used buttermilk instead of regular milk, and only enough to make the dough hold togetherit only took about 3/4 cup. I'd assume that the people whose biscuits were too dense just didn't need to use as much milk. Also, I'm a bit lazy, so I kneaded the dough right in the bowl, and just placed globs of it on the cookie sheet rather than roll it out. The biscuits turned out great (although they'd have been prettier if I'd rolled them out). Instead of refrigerating the dough, you can freeze it once you've formed the biscuits; just pop the frozen biscuit dough in the oven, and add about 5 minutes to the baking time.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/58165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried an endless number of biscuit recipes and this is now my Official recipe for biscuits. The original recipe is perfect as-is but I've made some variations (substituted 1 C. AP flour for 1 C. white whole wheat flour or added grated cheese and/or herbs) with great results too. Also, you can make this in a FOOD PROCESSOR: Put all dry ingredients in processor and pulse a few times. Then add small, cut-up chunks of the shortening (sometimes I use cold butter) and pulse until coarse. Add milk a little at a time (you might not need all of it) until the dough pulls away from the sides of the bowl and turns into a ball . Flatten dough with your hands (I skip the rolling pin) and proceed as directed. From start to eat, less than 1/2 hour! Thanks for the recipe!

userID:
2872745
Display Name:
maggi-lu
isPro:

0

6

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe 5 stars based only on taste for now, due to my lack of biscuit making experience (I'm sure) the texture wasn't what I hoped to achieve. I tried my best not to over-handle the dough, but perhaps I did, because they turned out pretty flat and dense, not light and fluffy like most of the others here.  They still taste wonderful and will not go to waste, but I look forward to trying this recipe again and hopefully perfecting it!

Update: I have tried this recipe again, this time with wonderful results, I did 3 things differently than I did the 1st time. 1) I used a large fork instead of my hands to work the butter in (I used butter both times), 2) I allowed the biscuits to rest in the fridge for 3 hours before baking, and 3) I set the oven a bit hotter, to 450, because they didn't seem quite done in the centers the first time.

My biscuits came out tall, light and fluffy this time, just as I was hoping, I'm so happy!

Mmmm...these are great!  I served them with vegetarian biscuits and gravy!  Update 5/14/17:  made these for strawberry shortcakes.  Added 3 tablespoons sugar and reduced the salt slightly. I think the amount of liquid would have to be decreased for a cut biscuit.  They come out like big, tender clouds.  :)  Sometimes have to cook these longer than recommended to get to brown (could be because I'm using all vegan ingredients).

Really great recipie, I dont know why anyone would waste their money buying biscuits ...They are so easy to make and delish!

I also roll these out thinner than the recipie calls (1/2 inch)--but I find them to be the perfect size.

userID:

Display Name:
Kristen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great biscuits!  I have made them a number of ways now.  Everytime I used butter rather than shortening, and soymilk rather than milk (lactose intolerance).  I also make sure I don't mix to much before the kneading part--just enough to hold it all together (rather like making pie dough).  I started making them before I had a biscuit cutter using a juice glass.  They had a decent rise (I was pleased) and they tasted great.  After awhile I had made them enough that I didn't read the directions when I would make them.  Turns out I should have because I left off the kneading part.  The biscuits definitely rose less this way (still using the juice glass to cut them out).  I did this two or three times before I figured out what I was doing wrong (duh).  I was curious whether a biscuit cutter would make even more of a difference--they are so inexpensive I bought some.  Awesome rise now and still soft with great flavor!!  My advice--knead and use biscuit cutters...and always read the directions ;)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
Very good biscuits. I made a double batch, ande it gave me about 30 biscuits(using a small cookie cutter). I used room temp.butter instead of shortening. I also flattened them thinner, and they still puffed up perfectly! Very tasty as well. Many pple said they were even better than Popeye's biscuits!!Update: For more flavor, I have made using a good sprinkle of pamesan cheese, and they were the ultimate!!...and oh...very important to note that you really have to mix the batter until it just comes together. Barely knead, otherwise they don't rise as much(I learned the hard way!)Thanks for the great recipe!

The biscuits did come out with a nice texture and they were pretty giant! The biscuits did taste a bit too "doughy". I guess it's due to the fact that I used Skim Milk - this is like adding water but that was the only milk I had on hand. I think using buttermilk and butter would help these biscuits taste less dry and have more moisture. 

The biscuits came out giant as promised from the author of the recipe. I was full after eating only one and a half and I usually can eat a lot more. Serving the biscuits with gravy is a plus as well. I used the recipe "Momma's Country Gravy" from this site with the biscuits

text:
Although these were nearly the best biscuits I've yet to make, I found that although I stuck to the recipe in ints entirety (...well almost- I accidentally went on kneading the dough for apprx. 15 mins., overlooking the fact that the recipe said 15-20 "times"), I thought that the recipe lacked in taste, texture and depth-they were kinda short and not so BIG. They weren't bad, though....I can see the possibilities of perfection with a few additions/alterations!

I used butter instead of shortening...Okay, y'all, I thought I had royally messed these up.  I used the entire cup of milk and it made the dough super gooey, so I had to keep sprinkling flour on it to get it to stiffen up.  I was afraid that it made me "over handle" the dough.  I don't have a rolling pin, so I just patted fairly evenly with my hands.  I had to do it twice and had one bicuit that I pieced together.  UNBELIEVABLE! That last, sad little bicuit is the one that I had fresh out of the oven with a puddle of butter and jelly and it was STILL fluffy and perfect!

text:
These were very easy and quick to make and oh so yummy!  My husband and kids got very excited over these.  It also makes the perfect amount for our family, versus other recipes that I have to scale back so I don't end up with 10 leftover biscuits!  I've made these twice, served once for breakfast with sausage gravy (made 24 hours in advanced, stored in refrigerator and baked in the RV while campling - so nice to just take out the dough and cook it - Yeah! No mess!) and then again a second time as a side to dinner.  I was wary of handling too much do to other reviews but found that I didn't handle them enough.  The ones that ended up rising the best were the last two biscuits that were made out of each batch - the ones that had been smushed together and then flattened out a few times.  So next time I will knead the dough per the recipe and see if they all will rise as beautifully as those last two.  Fantastic recipe!

I dont know whats wrong with people that change a recipe then complain that it didnt work!  Dont you know that when you change milk to buttermilk...it changes the amount the biscuits will rise?  When I make pancakes , I add a bit of water to the buttermilk.  It makes them fluffier, they rise beautifully !  One cook named Azuledive admitted that it might be her mistake...amen! Give credit to where credit is due..the only change you can make is half butter /half shortening...nothing else except spices...Thank you J.P.  I appreciate your sharing with us..

city:

country:

text:
These were lovely.  I kept exactly to the recipe and only kneaded 18 times. They rose beautifully.  Now - I live in England - and we call these savoury scones where I come from (I didn't realise until we were eating them!)  To make an English cream tea you make this recipe adding 1 heaped tablespoon of sugar to the recipe. Then serve then split in half across the way (making two discs) and topping each half with raspberry or strawberry jelly and then whipped up heavy cream - together with a hot cup of English tea of course.  We also eat savoury scones adding any combination of cheese, bacon, fried onion or grain mustard to this recipe.  Thanks for reminding me of all this John - I'm off to make some sweet and cheese scones!

text:
LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE this recipe.  I can believe that I made biscuits.  Every attempt I ever made resulted in rocks.                                     UPDATE 03/15/10:  These have become my secret recipe biscuits.  Remember to not overwork the dough more than you need to.  I like lg. biscuits and normally get 6 biscuits out of this recipe. After placing on parchment paper covered baking sheets I coat the biscuits with butter flavor cooking spray and cover with plastic wrap. I let the biscuits sit in a warm area and "rise" while I prepare the rest of the meal.

text:
This biscuit recipe was excellent. I used honey instead of sugar, used 1/2 whole wheat flour and 1/2 regular flour, and baked them on a baking stone. They turned out excellent! Next time I plan to double the recipe, add more wheat flour (I love grains), use cake flour in replace of the all purpose flour, and refrigerate over night to relieve me of hazzle for the morning I bake them.

text:
I had originally put this as 3 stars because they didn't come out right the first time, but I tried making them again today for Chicken and Biscuits and they turned out wonderful! They baked up nice and high and were fluffy on the insides. The problem I had before was that I kneaded the dough too much. Don't spend a lot of time kneading this dough.
The taste wasn't out of this world, but nothing butter, honey, or jam can't fix, plus I'm in Australia and biscuits here are what we call cookies so this recipe will do the trick and no doubt will take care of my biscuit cravings. Now to try and make homemade sausage for biscuits and gravy. I'm very excited about this!!
Thank you J.P. for such a great recipe!!!

text:
I'm in love - These were scrumptious! If you're watching your carbs or dieting or anything like that, you'd better watch your back, because these bad boys are addictive. They bake up big, moist and fluffy and are great with butter and honey or for soaking up really tasty gravy. For those that complained that they were plain, well, not to insult your intelligence, but it IS a straight-up biscuit recipe - if you want garlic, cheese, cinnamon or whatever you're going to have to either experiment or find another recipe tailored to exactly what you're looking for (although it's so easy to adapt this recipe that I'll never look elsewhere). J.P., you're my hero!

Very good biscuits! I have made these several times without any modifications to the ingredients and always came out great. text:
A big hit with the husband and toddler. We enjoyed them with country gravy and chicken for dinner, then with jelly the next morning. I anticipate making these a lot. When I rolled out the dough I folded it over, rolled it out again and did that a few times before cutting the dough with a glass. It created layers in the biscuits which made it easy to half and spread.

text:
This is my go to recipe for baking powder biscuits. I've made them many times now, usually as written but I've also found it to be very forgiving when I need to substitute an ingredient.

I've made these with water when I had no milk. Yes really.
I've made these with oil when I had no shortening.
They turned out fluffy when I forgot to kneed the dough that one time. In these times I'm thankful for the little things and this recipe is one of them.

text:
I make these using 1 to 1 Gluten Free flour (Krustez brand) and add about 1/4 cup more milk . Instead of rolling and folding, I do them as drop biscuits.  My GF friends love them and are so glad I included them in my cooking.  
*tip* Spray a little Pam* on your drop spoon before each scoop.  It helps them slide off the spoon.

text:
Very simple recipe and easy to follow.  I also used butter instead of shortening for the flavor.  The key to tender biscuits is to not overwork the dough so I kneaded it just a few times.  I also let the buscuits rest for about 20 minutes before baking to allow the baking powder to activate.  The buscuits turned out tall and  and tender: delicious and a hit with my sausage gravy.  Will make these again.

None
text:
So perfect! I used butter instead of shortening and prepared them a little differently than specified. I used a food processor to cut in the butter, and refrigerated the dough for about a half an hour before turning it out onto the counter. I rolled the dough out and tri-folded it twice in lieu of kneading before the final roll-out. I cut the biscuits out with a pop can I sliced in half; this worked exactly a million times better than the blunt edges of some of my cookie cutters. They were a big hit!

text:
I've been making biscuits for over 20 years and I have to say that these are by far the best I have ever made. I wanted buttermilk biscuits so I added a little vinegar to the milk. My dough was very wet, so when I turned it out onto a floured surface I just lightly kneaded to get it not sticky. The dough was very light. I didn't work it hard at all. They  raised high and were light and fluffy. They were melt in your mouth delightful. I baked at 450 for 10 min. but I don't think that made any difference. This is my new go to recipe from now on. Thank you!

text:
These biscuits were awesome. I used 6T. Butter instead of the shortening, and they were big and fluffy. Don't use a rolling pin...just use your hands to pat it down. And when you use a glass or cookie cutter to cut out the biscuit, don't twist it because it will impede the rising of the biscuit. I baked them for 14 minutes. I will definitely make these again!!

text:
This was a great recipe. I've tried many recipes for big and fluffy biscuits, only for them to look like a flat hockey puck. This one is great. The first time I made it, I followed the recipe exactly. The second time, I used some other reviewers tips and substituted butter for the shortening and it gave the biscuits more flavor. More salt would be ok too, if you like. Also, don't pour the whole cup of milk in, it will be too much. Do like the recipe says and pour a little at a time. I'd say I used 3/4 cup of milk total.

text:
Nice texture, very good fluffy soft insides and slightly crunchy, harder outside shell. I only used about 3/4 of a cup of milk. They baked for about 15-17 minutes. I also used all butter, I didn't have any shortening. They were perfect, except that they had little to no flavor. I think if you used buttermilk instead of regular milk, or normal milk instead of almond milk like I did, they would have had more flavor. Other than that they were REALLY GOOD. They also rose PERFECTLY! I made 9 biscuits instead of 6 fatter ones.

Display Name:
sbwreed

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Most excellent biscuits! i will definitely use this one again!
I made a couple changes...  The most important thing to know for those who don't have a lot of biscuit experience- recipes are subject to the environmental conditions where you cook. I've done them in TN, NJ, CO, CA, WA and NY. recipe and handling/baking was different in all locations. I do recommend you look at the video- this dough was a bit wetter than I'm used to, and if I hadn't looked at the video I probably would've added far too much flour and ended up with floury bricks, like some of the unhappy reviewers.

The only "shortening" I have in my house is coconut oil. I needed a bit more (about 2 extra TBS) to get the right consistency before adding the  milk, which I needed a bit less of- I'd say I used about 3/4 - 7/8 cup. 
I learned this last bit  while living in the south. After kneading and rolling out the dough, use a sharp knife (I always use my pizza slicer!) and cut the biscuits out. Every time you scrape the dough together and re-roll it to get more biscuits, they get a little tougher.  
 After putting the biscuits on your pan, put the pan in the fridge for at least 15 minutes to get your shortening of choice to firm up again.  Pop them in your preheated oven- and after preheating, let the oven stay at temp at least 15 minutes before adding the biscuits.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make these all the time, the only thing I do different is I do NOT knead the dough 14 or 15 times, I add the milk and stir for a second or two then flop it onto the lightly floured board, knead about 1 or 2 times until it sticks together, then roll or pat it out to about 1 1/2 inches thick, cut with a juice glass, put the biscuits onto a non- greased cookie sheet and bake,  they come out light and fluffy,  the extra kneading will make biscuits tough,the less you handle it the better.  (same goes for pie dough, if you knead it too much, you end up with a tough crust).

text:
Good when short on time and ingredients. I sift my flour, salt and baking powder together so its well incorporated. Great for stews or gravy. I also used margarine rather than shortening since that's what I had. I don't bother cutting round ones, just pat out the dough and cut squares with a sharp knife.  No left over dough or over-worked dough that way so always tender!!  Great and simple baking powder biscuits when I don't have stuff for my buttermilk recipe. Wonderful when teaching an 8yr old how to bake!  ;)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/42225.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used all butter (grated in, frozen.) I prefer the dough to be slightly wet and do all my mixing/kneading in the bowl with a spatula.  I turn the sticky dough onto a floured surface and sprinkle it with flour and roll it quickly into a thin sheet.  I followed another review and folded the sheet over once (if its too sticky, just use a knife or bench scraper to help it over.) Then use a floured cookie cutter to cut out 8 med. sized biscuits placed spaced apart in a foil lined cookie sheet.  Brush melted butter on top of each and baked mine for about 12 mins. always checking after the 1st 10 mins.  Oh, I also bake them on a rack moved up to the second highest level otherwise the bottoms get too brown before the tops get a chance to.  Very delicious!   Thank you, John!

Display Name:
mama

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think the biscuits were fabulous. For those of you who said the biscuits didn't rise, may I suggest you check the expiration date on your baking powder. Also, as many others have suggested, use a metal biscuit cutter (they usually have taller sides than a cooky cutter) a glass cutter will press the sides down rather than give you a clean cut) I used the food processor and they came together super quickly.  I didn't need all of the milk and, after reading many reviews, I think the original recipe should be revised to say 3/4-1 cup milk as the amount of milk can vary depending on the flour, humidity and who knows what else. The minimal amount of sugar makes the biscuits brown nicely.   Use BUTTER instead of shortening,  add the milk SLOWLY and brush the tops of the biscuits with melted butter BEFORE and AFTER baking  and you will have the the best biscuits ever!

12803256
Display Name:
Tanna
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I  pulled the biscuits from the oven several minutes ago and just popped the first one for a quick few bites: Biscuit nirvana! Many thanks to JP for sharing this great recipe. The biscuits have turned out nicely fluffy but also with a very slight crispiness to the outside which adds a certain robustness to the experience of biting into it. Like others on this forum, I made a few modifications which luckily did not result in damaging the quality of the biscuits. My modifications include:. 
1.) I used whole spelt flour. The texture and consistency of the biscuits is fabulous.
2.) I substituted coconut oil for the shortening - 75% of the amount of shortening the recipe called for.
3.) I also added just a bit of cold butter (approximately 1/3  cup) as it appeared that the mixture needed just a bit more fat.
I believe that the coconut oil may account for the lovely slight crispiness. It also added a subtle flavour to the bisquits.
4.) I also doubled the recipe.

In short: Yum!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Basic recipe. Changes that worked for me: 1/2 cup of softened BUTTER!!!, BUTTERMILK!!, Self Rising flour plus 1 teaspoon baking powder, 450 degrees (thermometer read), NO KNEADING, just get everything wet, then flour your hands and place the ball on floured countertop, hand form the dough to 3/4 to 1 inch thick (no rolling pin), cut and place biscuits on pie pan touching (I also use parchment paper). Brush tops with melted butter, Bake 11 to 14 minutes. check at 11 minutes.  If not brown on top, turn your oven to high broil and toast for about 90 seconds.  Fluffy, YUMMY!!!!

text:
I love this recipe!  I have made it a number of times and they always turn out well.  I never use shortening, substituting cold butter instead.  My other variations are to substitute 3/4 cup of the milk with yogurt, which allows me to use a little less of the butter.  I add a little extra milk if needed for the dough to come together.  The biscuits with yogurt are light and moist - delicious!  I have also made this recipe with almond milk, giving a lovely, nutty richness to the biscuits.  This is a can't-miss recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been trying out many different recipes and techniques to make what I think would be the perfect biscuit. This is it... they are dense but rose well. Some said these were bland, this is fixed by using butter instead of shortening ( it has salt). I have also added some finely shredded cheddar cheese or some parmesan and they were awesome. Some advice though...shake your baking powder or soda anytime you use it and replace it monthly if possible. second knead the dough minimally, I patted it to a large rectangle... folded left and right side into middle and then folded in half. then repeated 3x this creates the layers, roll out and cut ( no twisting)-simple but important tips I have learned along the way.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The ingredients are a good basic biscuit recipe, though I use half a cup of shortening and little or no sugar. Since it is a law of biscuit making to handle the dough as little as possible, I don't know why it calls for kneading--and 14 to 15 times!! If those babies aren't tough, then, I will be greatly surprised. I don't knead at all, and I don't use a rolling pin. Put the mixed dough out on a floured board, dust it with more flour, pat it into a round about 3/4 inch thick and cut into rounds. Gently does it. Bake as the recipe directs.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe several times now and it is outstanding! I learned from my grandmother that you never knead biscuit dough, just mix it until it comes together and stop; however, the first time I made these I followed that thinking and the first cut busicuts were not nearly as light or raise as much as the second cut biscuts (the biscuits I cut from the dough left over from the first set).  Now I wouldn't knead these like you would bread, but I would use the same type of motion, working the dough until it is less sticky and comes together.  I get great results every time with these.  So tasty and beautiful!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1835987.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice recipe if you're looking for something quick with the ingredients that you have in your kitchen. It requires little preparation and is done quickly. I thought the prep time was highly exaggerated, and would have said 10 minutes myself. Cook time was exactly 14 minutes for me. Would be longer if you used a larger cutter for the biscuits, which I would recommend and will be doing myself next time. I substituted unsalted stuck butter for the shortening. I did not over-kneed the dough, which would make them hard. I placed the biscuits touching on the sheet. Would suggest erring on the side of thick when rolling out dough. Yields a nice, fat biscuit. Nice no-frills recipe that reminds me of the simple old school Betty Crocker recipe, only a higher biscuit, which is nice. OH! Forgot to mention, add the milk slowly and stop when you have enough. I used a little under my one cup of milk.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been trying different non yeast biscuit recipes from allrecipes for months; probably 15 in all.  These are my favorite so far; moist, flavorful, and very easy to make.  I used evaporated milk, doubled the recipe and had 14 perfect large biscuits. I only kneaded 3 times, then patted down. I have learned that the less you handle the dough, the better the biscuit with non yeast recipes. In fact, I do not think you need to knead this dough at all. I live in the South and have been told that the secret to great biscuits is the flour and many Southerners only make biscuits with flour from Booneville Flour and Feed Mill in NC-I am going to order some flour from them and try this again.  Also someone made grits on a chef contest show (Top Chef or one of those) and the judges raved about the grits and they were from Booneville Flour and Feed also.  I am finally going to try those products.  I love Allrecipes and have made some wonderful meals from this site. I especially love to put in the 3 ingredients I have in my frig and chooose out of the recipes that come up; a great way to stretch the dollar.

text:
I have been hunting for a good biscuit recipe for...I don't know how long. These were easy and delicious baking powder buscuits. I used the food processor and it cut the prep to no time at all. The cup of milk made the dough a little wet so I added about a 1/4 cup additional flour. My buscuits nearly tripled in size, I patted them out to an inch and they were at least 2 1/2 inches after baking. They were still a little doughy inside after cooking for 13 min, but still delicious. I will pat out a little thinner next time and they should be perfect. *A tip I learned from Cook's Country Test Kitchen is to rotate your baking powder every six months or so because it looses it's potency. This may be why they rose so significantly. GREAT RECIPE!! Thanks for sharing.

Display Name:
sarah924

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been my go-to biscuit recipe for years! Love them! For those of you coming out with tough or dry biscuits, it's because you're rolling the dough out too thin and/or over kneading the dough. I made this mistake a few times when I first started making homemade biscuits which turned out more like hockey pucks. So what you do is after kneading it only for about a minute or less, roll the dough out to about 1 inch thick (which is very thick), cut out circles, and then repeat until the dough is used up. This will give you huge fluffy biscuits every time :) I guess this is what the recipe says to do, but I'm just reiterating the importance of not rolling the dough to thin or over kneading b/c it's crucial! Also, make sure that your butter or shortening is cold.

text:
For my first time making biscuits, and for the fact that I made these to quench a sudden, intense craving for biscuits, these were okay. Not exactly good, but they weren't bad. They came out more cakey than flaky (which may be my own fault, considering I used butter instead of shortening) and entirely too salty, and after baking for 13 minutes the bottoms were burnt and the biscuits as whole were slightly dry.
This recipe is basic and has potential- next time I'll use shortening as the recipe suggests, cut the salt in half and check the biscuits after 11-12 minutes instead of 13. But for now, it only gets 3 stars.

text:
I search high and low for different Biscuit recipes & I thought I would give J.P.'s a shot, I am glad I did! Great recipe, I tweak just about every recipe I see from anywhere & this one was no exception. I replaced the Milk with Buttermilk & used Butter in place of the shortening. Other than that I stuck to the recipe, which made eight nice big & fat, thick bisquits. Brushed the top with melted Butter and baked them for around 18 mins. at 425 deg. F. They were perfect, flaky & tall as you ever seen in a Bisquit. My whole family loved 'em! This recipe just moved to the front of the pack for our go to Bisquits. Thanks for sharing!

text:
OMG these are perfect! I used vegetable oil and substituted white for light yellow sugar (that is the only one I had) - since it is less sweet than white I added about 1 tbsp more. I also substituted milk for buttermilk, and since it was non fat I added an extra splash of oil. I spread some egg yolk on them for pretty glossy top. The dough was soft and very easy to roll and handle. I made them in 5 min and they were ready in 15. My grandma would be proud. Super delicious!

5912271
Display Name:
Rani Ness

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5831998.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe as is, though to make it oversized, we add extra milk so we start with a very wet dough, then we knead the very wet dough on a heavily, heavily floured surface - dusting the top of the dough heavily, but working in only as much flour as is needed.  Really tender dough can result this way as well.  ALTER AT TIMES AS FOLLOWS:  1a)  half whole wheat (shorter rise, but a nice crispness sets in if it is allowed to brown fully - really yummy in a different way - I personally prefer biscuits this way, but not everyone will), 1b)  use raw sugar if using whole wheat, as there are more minerals which are really good for you.  and/or 2)  substitute a scant 1/3 C powdered milk, then use more than one cup, still turn out the very wet dough on a heavily floured surface.  It is harder for *us* to overwork the dough this way.  Whatever works for you, though.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe along with many other biscuit recipes this one was the best but I felt it still lacked flavor. I tweaked this recipe many times and am very happy with the final result. Sub: 2 1/2 tsp baking powder & 1/4 tsp baking soda, 1 1/2 tsp salt, 2 tsp sugar, 5 tbs salted butter (melted/softened), 1/2 c milk & 1/2 c buttermilk. The mix will be really gooey, use 1/4 c flour to flour surface before kneading. I hope you love my changes. 
momscreolekitchen.blogspot.com

Isn't it funny that all around the world things are called different names. 
In Australia - these are called Scones and are best eaten with strawberry jam and whipped cream. 

Or an alternative would be to boil some pumpkin and mash it through to make Pumpkin Scones.

I had never made biscuits before. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made two variations of this recipe - the first in which I just placed the dough on top of a slow cooker chicken pot pie and let it cook for several hours, and the second in which I cut circles in the dough, placed them on a tray and baked them in the oven. The first time I made the mixture it was a bit too runny so I made a second batch with slightly less milk. Either way, the pot pie biscuit mix and the biscuits made in the oven had an entirely different texture! The first was very doughy and almost like bread and the second batch was definitely British scones. We'll be using this again but I'm not sure what changed the texture or what I can do to make the bread-ish consistency again. This made perfect scones, but I'll be searching for a slightly different recipe as I'm certain that American biscuits are meant to taste a little bit different from scones, right? I've heard of cornstarch or maize being used so I'll have to experiment. Still, worked great both times but not sure why they turned out so different!

text:
If I could give this recipe 6 stars, I would!  It was my first time making these biscut and they were awsome.  They rose soo high I should have taken a picture.  Even more so, the family LOVED them.  I dont have a food processor, so I mixed these in a bowl as in the directions.  I cut the buttter up before hand and then put it in the freezer to get real cold.  After I mixed the butter in with the flour, I actually put the mix in the freezer again for about 7 minutes and then kneaded it, and rolled the biscuts  as directed.  These turned out wonderfully.  I have a new go to recipe!

text:
My #1 go to biscuit recipe, flaky and soft and tasty! I add half butter, and half shortening, butter for flavor and shortening for texture, just make sure whatever fat you use is ice cold, i put it in the freezer for 10-15 mins. I also add a TBSP of fresh thyme and a cup of sharp cheddar cheese, reduce salt to 3/4 tsp if using cheese :) Chives also work well in this recipe. I put the flour, sugar, salt, BP and the cheese+thyme uf using in my food processor, pulse 3 times, then add the butter and pulse 7 times, then add the shortening and pulse 5 times, then i switch to the plastic blade and mix on low while adding the cold milk slowly untill the dough comes together (I rarely use the entire cup of milk, it depends on the humidity and brand of flour that you use). I then cut into 6 rounds and let it rest in the fridge for an hour or so, then I brush with eggwash and bake in a preheated 350 F oven untill golden brown ( 15 mins or so)...to die for! Absoloutly heavenly! Thanks a bunch JP :)

text:
Good recipe.  I used butter instead of shortening and did not need the dough.  I also needed the full amount of milk but next time I may not.  I would suggest first pouring half the amount of milk into the flour mixture and then add more as needed.  After cutting out the biscuits, I placed them in the fridge for 25 minutes.  In addition to this, I brushed butter on each of the biscuits after 7 minutes of baking.  I then put the biscuits back in the over and baked for 5 more minutes.  The biscuits cooked for a total of 12 minutes.

text:
I have gone through countless biscuit recipes and can never seem to find one that I like.  This one is AMAZING.  So fluffy!  The inside is soft and moist and the outside has a subtle crunch to it.  I used 1/2 cup of dehydrated milk and 1/2 cup 1% milk (all we had in the house.) which required just a LITTLE more flour while kneading.  Other than that, I did the recipe as written.  We loved them and this will be the biscuit recipe I use from now on.  And they're so easy!

text:
These are now my go to biscuits. They're big and fluffy, not dry or hard like the product of so many other biscuit recipes that I've tried. I only had to use 3/4 of a cup of milk and I didn't knead the dough too much. As another reviewer suggested, I applied a thin layer of butter before and after baking. The biscuits were delicious. I'll definitely make these again.

text:
I read a bunch of the popular reviews and went with what they said.

My changes: used butter instead of shortening, made the dough in the food processor, and lightly rolled/kneaded it with a bunch more flour (since the dough was quite sticky).

I got 10 biscuits and they're delicious!  I'll be using this recipe from now on, it's so easy and quick!

text:
Being a southern-born woman, biscuits are a big thing to learn how to make as a kid.  I never did learn how to make good biscuits.  They always turned into rocks or had so much butter or shortening that they melted all over the pan.  This recipe is the best I have ever come across for both the ease and resulting biscuit.  My husband and I use this for our Saturday/Sunday biscuit and gravy breakfasts.  I make the biscuits and he makes the gravy from scratch.  We have always gotten rave reviews on them from our family.  So if J.P. has any other tasty and easy ideas for food, I think I will have to check them out, because so far so delicious!!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I loved this recipe. The only change I made was that I used butter instead of shortening ( I didn't have any shortening). I put the dry ingredients and butter in the food processor and let it blend on low for a minute. I took that mixture and put it in a bowl. I added 2/3 cup of milk and pulled the dough together by hand. I chilled the dough while I made most of the rest of the meal then flattened the dough gently with my hands. I used a biscuit cookie cutter to form dough. I baked the biscuits at 400 degrees for approximately 10 minutes (my gas oven cooks hot and fast). These were wonderful with the goulash and would be very good for breakfast with jam. THANKS!

text:
Makes a GREAT VEGAN BISCUIT! I made these with Earth Balance instead of shortening, and regular soy milk instead of milk. Mine always take a bit longer to bake (almost 20 minutes), but they're always worth it. Great plain with Earth Balance or with some preserves. 

For a hearty meal, throw some Smart Ground sausage (cut and flattened into patties) on a pan with a little canola oil over medium-high heat for 5 minutes, place on biscuit, and add some Daiya (vegan cheese) for an awesome vegan breakfast you didn't think was possible.

My family loved this recipe.  They continued to go back for more biscuits after the first serving.  I followed other reviewers' suggestions and used butter instead of shortening and mixed every thing up in the food processor for a super fast processing.  They came out very fluffy and golden brown.  Will definitely make them again; I tip, DO NOT knead them too much OR add too much flour when kneading as this can make the biscuits a little hard.

text:
I am eating these, freshly made, as I type this.  I had no clue if I was doing things right.  Having read quite a few reviews, I put in 3-3.5 teaspoons of baking powder and I tried not to knead the dough but it seemed unavoidable (I tried to limit it as much as possible).  It was really sticky and I wasn't sure if that was a good thing or not so I wrapped it in foil and popped it into the refridgerator for about 30 minutes - baked them at about 350 degrees for 15 minutes and they are great - soft, fluffy (though not particularly huge), and they taste great.  Will def try 'seasoning' them next time!

I made these using half white flour & half wheat flour, no sugar and used Spectrum shortening. I used my food processor. I pulsed all dry ingredients first. Cut in the shortening, pulsed. I then drizzled in the milk while pulsing. Kneaded just a few times on a floured cutting board. These turned out great. Next time I think I will brush with butter before baking though.

text:
Love, love, love this recipe. When I first starting making these biscuits I decided to substitute shorting for butter. Well, one day I ran out of butter and only had shorting. Decided to make the biscuits like the recipe says, and boy was I missing out. Using the shorting was SOOO much better! I'm so mad I waited this long to try it out. The biscuits were light, fluffy, with a little crunch on top (I did drop biscuits) This will forever be a winner in my recipe book.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG! Amazing!  My husband takes tremendous pride in his biscuts, and my daughter had these and told him (completely unprompted!) that he has to use this recipe from now on. lol. I was unable to follow the recipe exactly because I was out of shortening (I hate it when someone uses stuff up and doesn't tell me!!!) and I had to sub margarine. Since I used margarine, I omitted the salt. I also slowly added the milk as suggested by reviews and only ended up using about 3/4 of what the recipe said. I also decreased the baking soda as suggested by reviewers to 2.5 tsp.  Having said all that, can't WAIT to make them with the shortening, they must be truly amazing made correctly!**Have made these A LOT in the past month!  They are even better with the shortening, and also with butter flavored shortening! Have had a bunch of people ask for the recipe...have noticed that the amount of milk does affect how they turn out..also how much they are handled does as well so handle them as little as possible, and use less milk than called for. Still love these!

UNIQUENESS2

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are what you call weight gains, because if you eat enough of these grand lip smacking biscuits...you are sure to put on a lb. or two. I tried many on this site and now I can finally stop looking.  Whoo! Hoo! The only changes I made was used buttermilk instead of reg. milk (didn't have any) sub cold butter for the shortening, and right before I place them in to bake...I brushed melted butter on tops and the sides.  I baked on the middle rack for 15 min. then and additional 5 min on the top rack to brown evenly.  I took them out and brush the remaining melted butter on tops and sides.  Yummy, yum, yum!  I am going to try this once again but prepare the dough the night before to see if it indeed rises a little higher.  I will post the results once again.  Oh! One more thing...I got exactly 6 biscuits and 1 little scraped dough, this recipe is to the tee if you have a large mouth coffee cup like I did. 3/12 inch opening.

These biscuits were very tasty.  I made similar changes according to some of the reviews:  buttermilk instead of milk and 2 tsp. baking powder and 1/2 tsp. baking soda.  Although I tried to limit the "handling" of the biscuits, they didn't come out as fluffy as I would have liked.  I always use organic whole wheat pastry flour when I bake, so perhaps next time I'll sift the flour to add a little more air.  Still, a GREAT recipe and one that I will continue to use!

text:
Want to add a nice kick to these biscuits?  Add 1 Tablespoon white vinegar to the milk and let it sit for a few minutes before adding to the flour.  Now you will have buttermilk biscuits!  If possible, use BUTTER instead of shortening!  It's the lesser of the two evils!

text:
If I could give these more stars I would.  Basic, no frills, excellent biscuit recipe.  I've made them several times now, each time they come out perfectly, and store nicely.  I think with a bit more sugar they would be perfect for shortcakes as well! UPDATE: This is still my go to biscuit recipe, it has yet to yeild less than scrumptious results.  I did, however, forget to mention in my initial review that I usually have to add in a bit more flour than is called for in order to be able to work with them, I think 2 cups leaves the dough a bit too wet for me (I usually start with 2 1/4 cups then add as I knead).  I've also rolled the dough out into a large rectangle and spread ground sausage (uncooked) over the top, then rolled and sliced before baking for sausage pinwheels and they turn out delicious too!  Just lower the temp a bit and extend the baking time to account for the meat.  Once again, FABULOUS RECIPE.

10/21/10 - I think I've got this recipe to work for us.  Although still a very, very, very sticky dough which I drop from a muffin scoop, the rise and taste is better. DH said they tasted like Bisquick biscuits, too moist and rated it a 2.  DS loved them and rated them a 5.  I thought the salt taste came through (I used Kosher salt) and they were crumbly.

text:
These biscuits are GREAT! There are fluffy and melt in your mouth good. Things to remember: do not knead the dough and overmix. I used 1 1/2 Tablespoons of baking powder to make them rise a little more and I baked these at 375* so it all bakes nice and steady. I used butter and shortening together but just butter is good too. I also let them rise covered up for 30 minutes to make them taller but that's only if you have time. These were great, this is my new biscuit recipe for life =D

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these to serve with a homemade Minestrone soup.  I have always used my Grandmother's tea bisuit recipe (wonderful fluffy and a family tradition), but thought I'd try these.  I probably will never make my Grandmother's bisuits again - these were fantastic.  Huge, light and fluffy.  My husband liked them so well, he asked me to make for breakfast the next day.  Comment on one review.  They do need to be kneaded!  Please do not skip this part.  It only takes moments and make a difference and make sure you do use your pastry cutter to make the mixture a fine "crumble" before adding milk.

These biscuits came out light and as tall as the picture, with a great crumb. So far this is the best recipe I've found here for biscuits,so many others were disappointments. I used half butter and half shortening. I had to use a bit more flour when folding but the results were still fantastic. I'll use this as my go to recipe when I need biscuits from now on. They heated well the next day in the microwave and were moist as the day I made them.

country:
None
text:
I've had this recipe in my recipe box for several years now and decided to make it tonight when I needed a bread to go with our roasted turkey legs and carrots.  I substituted butter for the shortening and accidentally added a little too much milk.  I was afraid I would overwork the dough if I added more flour, so I just greased my hands and formed them into circles, then baked them in a round cake pan.  No kneading.  I brushed them with butter before and after baking them.  The result?  My fiance took one bite and said they were the best biscuits he'd ever had.  I'm giving up Alton Brown's recipe and will be using this one from now on!  They're tender, flavorful, tall, everything you could want in a biscuit.

text:
Best homemade biscuits I've ever made!  No more hockey pucks for us :o)  I used my food processor, pulsing the ingredients as little as possible.  I sliced butter flavored crisco & stuck it in the freezer while I prepared the dry ingred. & I used buttermilk instead of milk.  I didn't roll them out, just patted them lightly into the right thickness.  Be sure to make the dough nice & thick before you cut them.  They turned out soooo tender & very flavorful!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I loved these biscuits! Just like from the can but better! I followed the recipe exact, and actually had to use a little bit more milk than called for. I rolled them up in foil and let them sit overnight in the fridge. In the morning all I had to do was cut them and bake them. I made 6 jumbo biscuits and they baked perfectly. I didn't know making biscuits from scratch was so easy! But my husband thought they were just ok, he asked if they had butter, because he wanted more of a buttermilk biscuit, so next time I might melt some butter on top the dough before baking for him.

text:
We love this recipe.  The biscuits are everything we want in a biscuit- big (they raise high as they bake), soft (you can pull them appart), and delicious.  We have them with butter and honey, sausage gravy, or with strawberry shortcake.  My tips to having them turn out especially good is not to cut the shortening in too small, not to overmix the ingredients when adding in the wet, and not to add any more milk than needed.

This recipe is fantastic! I subbed butter for shortening and powdered sugar for the white sugar. Definitely be sure to add the milk as needed, rather than all at once. If you have the time, it pays to let the dough refrigerate for as long as possible. These were very easy to make and delicious to eat! They're very versatile and have a great buttery flavor! I made them last Sunday for breakfast, and last night for dinner to go with a creamy chicken, carrot and pea sauce.

country:
None
text:
Fluffiest biscuit I have had in a long long while.  I did make some changes though.  I had some buttermilk I needed to get rid of so I used that and I didn't have shortening so I used some unsalted butter.  Updated:  So I had an old stand mixer that I had had for a while.  You know, one of those 300 dollar Kitchenaid's.  I used it to cut the butter and mix the dry ingredients.  Poured the buttermilk and mixed by hand in the bowl.  I need the dough a few times just to get everything together and then just flatten by hand.  There is no need to use a rolling pin.  I make about 11 to 12 biscuits from this recipe depending on how thin I press it.  I take them to work everyday and warm them up for breakfast.

text:
These were fantastic!  I baked them to go with homemade turkey soup last night.  Even though I doubled the recipe, between my boyfriend and our roommate, I only had two biscuits left this morning!  I will definitely be making these again!  A few notes: I used butter instead of shortening.  I didn't knead these at all.  I just mixed them until they came together and then patted them into a round.  I let the dough rest in the fridge for about 2 hours before I cut and baked the biscuits.  Thanks for sharing!!

text:
So easy and so good! Mine didn't end up all that huge, but I'm fairly sure that was my fault. I did a little too much tinkering with the dough while patting out and cutting. I made the dough several hours before baking it... wrapped it in greased foil, refrigerated, then took out and let it set on the counter for about an hour. They baked up perfectly in 15 minutes. Fluffy, light, and great taste! I brushed the tops with melted butter when they came out of the oven to keep them soft. Thank you, I can't wait to make breakfast sandwiches with the leftover ones in the morning! :)

text:
Yummy!  I doubled the recipe and yielded about 14 large biscuits, although I made the dough only about 3/4" thick.  I stuck the whole cookie sheet in the fridge for about 3 hours before baking.   Because the pan and biscuits were cold, cooking time was a little longer ... about 18 minutes.  (Note: Refrigerate the shortening for an hour before mixing with the flour will make a flakier texture ... just like when making a pie crust!)

text:
I made the recipe as written except I subbed buttermilk for the regular milk because that is how my Mom always made her biscuits.  My problem with biscuits has always been the ratio of how much of everything I need to put in!   I thought the recipe had a good flavor and they did rise nicely so I gave the recipe a 4 star rating.  The actual biscuit was probably a 3 star, but, that is entirely my fault because I think I overworked the dough and they were a little tough. I'll just have to keep practicing!! UPDATE: 7/6/17 I decided to give these another try and this time had much better luck.  I followed the advice of another reviewer and refrigerated the dough for about 30 minutes before I rolled it out.  I don't know if that was it or the fact that I was very delicate in working the dough, but, the biscuits were much more tender than my previous attempt.

text:
These are great tasting biscuits! I would suggest to anyone that is making them and want them to be big, they won't rise so much as with store bought, they add a bunch of addivties to theirs, these are "homemade" so when you "pat" not roll, them out make them the thickness you want, they will rise a tad but you will get the results you want! Make sure you mix this well to, so that way you don't end up with biscuits that fall apart. TY 4 sharing

text:
Knead or not knead biscuits. Seems to me that there are two schools of thought.  Do both work?  I pat and fold 4 times, then roll and fold once.  After the biscuits are cut, the next batch made from the scraps gets extra handling and are just as good and tender, they may even rise better.  The advocates of kneading  agree.

text:
Okay, I've been making these for awhile and my family loves them.  But we had a little dilemma yesterday when the kids wanted cinnamon rolls and hubby wanted biscuits.  So, I made the dough, then rolled it out into rectangle shape.  I sprinked brown sugar and cinnamon and rolled it cinn. roll style and pinched the seam.  Sliced the roll in 1 inch pieces, baked them, drizzled with icing.  OMG!  I cannot make them this way too often, could not stay away!  I was a rock star with my family!!

text:
Awesome biscuits, just amazing!  One thing I have to tell myself whenever I make these:  The dough must be rolled thick.  Thick.  Thick.  Thick.  I have to keep chanting this or I roll them out too thin and get J.P's Little Daddy Biscuits.  I roll my dough to about 3/4"-1" thickness- like a hockey puck- and they get HUGE in the oven.

Pretty good.  I read some reviews that said they were a little bland so I added 1/2 tsp onion powder, some black pepper, chopped chives and used half shortening/half butter.  We ate them with sausage gravy!  I'll definitely make these again but I'll probably play with the spices a little. UPDATE: I made these exactly as the recipe stated -wonderfully flaky!  I had to bake for about 22 minutes.  Next time I'll omit the sugar and add more salt and add butter to the tops!

userID:

Display Name:
Bengali

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice - very fluffy and moist!  One tip that I found was beautiful with them; brush the top with butter and then sprinkle with your choice of cheese; bake until cheese is golden and bubbly; or even put a little pocket of cheese inside; instead of patting (works better than rolling; biscuits turn out fluffies) the dough to 1" do to 1/2 " and on top of one circle; put about a tablespoon of mild cheese (or to your taste) and put another circle on top; and very lightly press the edges down to just adhere the edges slightly.  Or use more sugar and a bit less salt with unsalted butter and put a tablespoon of jam or fruit in the middle instead of the cheese.  Yum!!

2927476
Display Name:
tinteardrop
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's a good solid recipe. I added 2 TBS buttermilk powder (I would have used buttermilk instead of milk if I had it). You may not need one cup of liquid - I didn't so don't go past 3/4 cup at first and see how the dough is. Don't overmix it or they will not rise well. Make sure your oven is at the correct temperature before you put them in.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Just reading the reviews on this recipe, I had to try it. I didn't have any milk but did have a little half and half and a little cream, so I combined them and added water to make a cup. I also used butter rather than shortening, again just because I didn't have any. Lovely fluffy biscuits. I will do this again! I followed one of the reviews that said to knead gently, so ended up with maybe 7-8 times. Just beautiful!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
All I have to say is: Awesome! I ended up making these two or three nights in a row, my friends loved them so much. (Besides, I won't pass up an opportunity to practice my biscuit making skills!) It does take a try or two to perfect these, but it really is worth it!! 

I agree with other reviewers, add the milk a little at a time, you won't always need all of it.

Biscuits require a really soft hand, and this dough needs little, if any, kneading. Just rolling out the dough to form the biscuits will usually be enough. 

Leave the unused dough in the fridge between batches. The longer you can let the dough set in the fridge, the bigger they rise. 

This is going at the top of my list. Perfect for any biscuit occasion.

text:
I really liked these.. I have tried for a very long time to make biscuits. Nothing I seemed to try worked at all. Until now. I've made these 3 times so far and have had nothing but compliments from my hubby. The last time I made them, I rolled the dough thin and brushed the top with melted butter before folding. I did this about 15 times and had 'peelable' layers. It's very time consumming, but well worth it. The biscuits didn't raise as high by doing this, but still were taller biscuits compared to others that I have made. Thanks for providing such as easy recipe!!!!

text:
This is a good basic recipe and better than other baking powder biscuit recipes I've tried. We have these often for breakfast with milk gravy.

When I make them I use bacon grease for the shortening (no Crisco available where I am) and UHT milk. I've even made this recipe with water when there's no milk in the house; the recipe is still tasty, although the texture is a bit different (lighter and less dense than with milk).

text:
beautiful biscuit, tall, rustic looking, but I'm sensitive to the taste of baking powder and baking soda and immediately wanted to cover that taste up w/jam. even so, there was still that familiar aftertaste, as I suspected there would be. nice and soft, nice consistency, too salty though. I should have left out the salt since I used salted margarine. I will definitely make these for others because I don't think people are as sensitive to the taste of baking powder as I am. mine came out like a scone, crispy outer layer, soft and light on the inside, which I love. no kneading, just a couple turns. I think most people would be very happy w/these.

text:
Excellent!! Few tips. A pastry dough cutter works the best to work in the shortening or hard butter To get crumbles. If dough is sticky had a little more flour in as you knead. Dont over knead ?. Leave the dough the full 1 inch thick for a great big soft yummy biscuits. Make sure they are a light brown or they wont be done in the middle. These are great.

text:
I have been making this recipe for several years now. It's a great go-to recipe, easy and quick. It's also a very hearty biscuit, yummy with biscuits and gravy or strawberry shortcake. My advice, don't over mix or over knead and I once I pat my dough out I cut them with a knife instead of using a glass or round cutter. Yes, you'll end up with square biscuits, but they taste just as yummy and you've saved yourself some time and effort.

This is the best biscuit recipe I've ever tried!  Simple and scrumptious!  (Ok, I wrote this review almost two years ago and I wanted to update it.  I always use this recipe and have made these probably 20 or 30 times.  I've found that kneading the dough lightly and quickly and not messing with it much, gives the best results.  I pat it out to about an inch thick, cut out with my biscuit cutter and bake as directed.  Everyone loves my biscuits!  Thanks, John, for submitting the recipe!)

text:
I first used this recipe for a chicken and dumplings recipe on this site.  The dumplings came out great.  The second time, I made them for biscuits and gravy, and they turned out nice and tall - gorgeous, in fact, but they were a little dry and kind of bland.  I would probably make them again, but not before trying some other recipes to see if I find one I like better.  *Okay, I just keep making them.  I tried them following the recipe without really kneading the dough and didn't notice an improvement.  This time, I made them with butter, and added cheddar cheese to half the batch.  These were received MUCH more favorably by both husband and son.  I will probably use these again (they're so easy!).  I cut mine at 1/2 inch thickness because while the WOW factor is cool, who really needs/wants four inch high biscuits?  :)

text:
WOOHOO!  I was beginning to think I would never be able to make decent biscuits as an adult (much to the chagrin of my Southern ancestors), but last night I proved myself wrong!  These biscuits are AWESOME!!!  I would give this recipe 10 stars if I could.  The biscuits rose to perfection and were lightly browned in about 15 minutes.  We served them with butter, homemade grape jelly, apple butter, and peach syrup.  It was a little piece of heaven on earth!  I got 10 good-sized biscuits out of this recipe instead of 6 mondo ones.  The only thing I might do differently next time is use butter instead of shortening.  Otherwise, don't change a thing!  THANKS J.P.!  :oD

text:
I make these on average about 1 sometimes twice a week. These are by far the best biscuits I have ever made.  I tweak them a little here and there depending on my mood. These have been refered to as velvet. I make these for my husband to take to work with some soft butter and honey and look out they are gone in 5 minutes.  I always double or even triple the recipes.  Leftovers what can I say biscuits and gravy. MMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM pure heaven. My kids adore them and when asked should I make JP Big Daddy's and it's a loud yes yes yes by 4 of my 5 kids.  Great recipe don't be afraid to tweek it just a tad, little more sugar, little less milk, less shortening and some butter.  Works well with powdered milk to, some cinnomon and nutmeg. Very versitle.

text:
This recipe is really great. I have made it several times to rave reviews. The key is to spend a long time cutting the shortening into the flour. I've tried it with both butter and crisco, and if you're up for a real treat -- the butter gives the biscuts a wonderful, rich flavor. I roll out the dough a little thicker, so that they will be nice and puffy out of the oven.

text:
I attempted to make biscuits 3 times today in preparation for an upcoming party.  The first batch was Angel biscuits with yeast.  They didn't rise and looked/tasted more like English muffins than biscuits.  The second batch was southern buttermilk biscuits, which were dense and didn't rise.  The third batch was J.P.'s big daddy biscuits.  Success at last!  I will stick with this recipe and make/freeze several more batches tomorrow.  Thanks for saving the day, J.P.!

i just made these after reading some of the other posts. i used butter flavored crisco, 3/4 C milk, and a little less baking powder. i also spread melted butter flavored crisco on top before baking. they baked perfectly, although i think i may have let them in a minute too long (i cooked them for 13 minutes). the only reason i'm giving this 4/5 stars is because of the aftertaste. i don't know if i should have used less baking powder and more sugar, but it was a little bitter. still, the biscuits themselves turned out VERY moist and delicious, when buttered.

This recipe is SO easy - I just threw everything in my stand mixer, used the dough hook to knead it, and then plopped six handfuls on to a cookie sheet. I used non-hydrogenated margarine (that nice olive oil flavoured Becel) instead of shortening, and half whole wheat flour. I also used half evaporated milk and half skim milk for the liquid. They looked and tasted perfect; thank you!

text:
I multiplied this recipe by 5, divided dough in thirds, kneaded it 15 to 20 times each, put it in a bowl with a lid.  An hour later we arrived at the church potluck.  I patted out each section of dough and cut about 35 - 40 biscuits.  This took less time than the oven did to heat.  5 minutes is all the longer they lasted.  I got rave reviews.  Everyone loved them!  And easy, too.

This first time I made these I thought they were good but needed something.  I made them again adding 1/2 teaspoon cream of tartar for rising effect, cutting the baking powder to 4 teaspoons and used 3/4 cup of milk then 1/4 cup of melted butter.  They were better after the additions.

text:
Reading the all instructions is important! I added all ingredients, kneaded, and cut the biscuits out. I came out with about 21 biscuits. Maybe I need to pull out my seam guide that I use for sewing to determine what an inch is. I am now reading that I was supposed to get 6 huge biscuits. If you didn't read the instructions thoroughly and came out with what I did, these would be good for a brunch filled with jams and jellies. Also, I used butter flavored shortening in a stick form. This gave my biscuits a nice color before putting them in the oven and also made it much easier for me to measure.

userID:
26961389
Display Name:
Jen
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I  made an account just so I could rate this recipe. I'm very critical of biscuits, and my husband married me for my ability to make biscuits and gravy. I have always been searching for the perfect recipe until I made this one. I always double the recipe now because it's a feeding frenzy when I make them. Sometimes I use butter instead of shortening if I'm feeling a little more southern. The trick for a fluffy biscuit is to not mix the dough too much and use REALLY cold butter or  shortening. You can also refrigerate the biscuits after they are cut and prior to cooking to get the fats solid again. Sometimes I even make these the night before and leave the cut biscuits in the fridge overnight and they end up HUGE (YUGE, even). If you're feeling rich you can even brush the tops with melted butter as soon as they come out of the oven.

userID:
1753645
Display Name:
MountainGirl4
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/154.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved these biscuits!  After reading reviews we tweaked the recipe in the following ways:  We omitted the sugar.  Once the dough was made we patted it out, folding it in thirds 3 times before cutting the biscuits.  We followed another reviewers advice about placing  biscuits in pan touching one another and melting butter in preheated pan first and coating biscuits on both sides with the melted butter just before placing into oven.  
These small changes to this wonderful recipe gave us flakey, layered biscuits that were slightly crispy on both the tops and bottoms but fluffy on the inside.  Couldn't ask for a better biscuit!  These were scrumptious right out of the oven and toast up deliciously as left-overs.  Gave this a 4 star rating because of the changes I made.

None
text:
I followed recipe as written for a couple batches; them made alterations.
changes as follows...
I added 1 tablespoon of vinegar to the milk to sour it. I added a teaspoon of baking soda to the flour mixture along with the recommended amount of baking powder. 
I increased the sugar to 3 tablespoons.
Lastly I placed biscuits on the prepared pan but put sides touching and cooked for additional 3 - 5 minutes (or until tops are a light golden. I immediately buttered the tops pf biscuits when removed from oven.   I found that my alterations made the biscuits Taller softer and delicious. this is my go to now. they are [nearly] as fast as canned biscuits but made with a lot more LOVE.

Best one, I have tried some recipe before but this one is easy and practical and result is a amazing light biscuit . just some notes: 1- I used half baking powder and half baking soda 2-oven must be very hot so the biscuit will start to bubble up and get light 3-I add about a teaspoon Cinnamon to it which helped with taste and its look 4-I used about 70 g butter instead  5-baked it for 45 min and then grill it above about 4 mins

None
text:
These are excellent biscuits!!!!  But I would like to write about something else.  It doesn't seem to matter what the biscuit is, if I bake it for the allotted time, the end product tastes like raw dough in my mouth.  I have discovered that if I bake biscuits waaaaay beyond the given time, they are way more palatable and become more bread-like.  I baked these for almost 25 minutes and they were wonderfully flaky and not-doughy.  Just something that I have discovered.  Thought I'd share this with y'all.

text:
I like this recipe but, as others have said, the milk amount is too much and should be stated in the ingredients list as a range; say 3/4 - 1 cup milk. 
That being said, I did add the whole cup of milk without paying attention to the "gradually" instruction and came out with a wet dough. But I made lemonade out of lemons by turning them into drop biscuits (I scooped them on the pan with an ice cream scoop).
One last note: I put them on an ungreased cookie sheet as instructed and they stuck to the pan. Next time I will use parchment paper. 
Very good biscuits, though, even after all of the hiccups :)

This recipe came out nothing like the picture.  The final product was shaped like a deflated balloon.  I have another recipe I normally use, but wanted a biscuit a bit more moist than usual. The outside was crisp and the flavor good, but not rising made the inside pretty dense.

userID:

Display Name:
Heather Worthy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6575515.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make these biscuits all the time for my family. My husband often requests that I make double batches just for him to keep as snacks.  I do substitute butter for the shortening. We once got low sodium baking soda by mistake and it made the biscuits very bland. For extra fluffy biscuits you can use self rising flour instead of all purpose flour.  I think some issues people have had may come from over mixing or using too much milk. Either use just the milk you need to make them the right consistency or add more flour if necessary. Unlike some reviewers I do knead the dough but not as many times as specified....just enough to change the consistency of the dough. I also roll them out onto a well floured mixing board. I normallly brush them with melted butter (sometimes garlic butter)  to add flavor  and make them extra crispy on the outside.

None
text:
I think maybe letting it rise longer would be better. With that being said - these were GREAT!  I changed the recipe to make whole wheat biscuits - a bit healthier.
 
I used 1/2 whole wheat flour in place of white flour and Bread flour in place  of all purpose.

I also used buttermilk in place of milk and followed another's suggestion of  baking powder and baking soda. The ratio was approx. 3 parts baking powder and 1 part baking soda.

The result was a good light biscuit - considering they were wheat (which I find tends to be denser).

My husband said that these are a keeper!

text:
I've never had any luck with biscuits but thought I would try once more. Since this recipe had more than 4K reviews, it seemed a good one. I made it as directed, using butter-flavored shortening, and my husband loved the biscuits. 

I read the reviews about cutting out and not trying to re-roll the leftover dough, so I patted the dough into a nice rectangle, then used a sharp knife to cut it into six pieces. Yes, the biscuits were rectangles instead of circles, but it didn't change the taste, and there was no waste.

text:
I would actually rate this recipe 3.5 stars, somewhere between it was OK and I liked it.  This is a pretty typical biscuit recipe, with a bit of extra baking powder.  For better texture, use White Lily Flour, or substitute half the AP flour with Cake Flour.  For added flavor, use whole fat buttermilk, and use butter instead of shortening, which has no flavor at all.
Review:

userID:
23626344
Display Name:
Orylie
isPro:

madeRecipesCount:
23
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These had good flavor. I used sour milk by adding a Tablespoon of vinegar to the milk and letting it sit  for 5 minutes.  I did not add sugar. The dough was a bit soft but I just added about 3 Tablespoons more flour and it was fine.

The key is not not knead the dough at all. Cut in the very cold butter and just mix lightly with a spoon or spatula till it barely comes together. Turn out onto a lightly floured surface and pat into a circle to your desired thickness. Don't need to roll it out just pat it out and then use a biscuit cutter and press straight down (don't turn while cutting the biscuits). 

I use a cast iron skillet. They did cook about 15 minutes as the dough was a little loose but the biscuits had a great flavor and were very light. Not dense at all. Good recipe.
Review:
Rating:
4

country:

text:
I made 1 1/2 recipe. Used unrefined cane sugar, mixed the dry ingredients, grated 1/2 cup frozen butter into it, pulsed a  few times in my food processor. Added the milk, pulse a few more times and turned out onto the counter. This dough was a stinker to work with! It was so soft and sticky that I had an awful time patting it out and then cutting it. I ended up cutting each piece with a biscuit cutter, scraping it up with a spatula, and then shaping into a vague disc. I ended up with 10 nice size biscuits. I was convinced that they would not turn out, but I baked them anyway. Im so glad that  I did because these are truly some of that thats biscuits that I have ever made. Just a bit sweet - great with sausage gravy or jam!
