text:
Great recipie. I use it all the time. Just remember buscuits are 20% recipie and 80% technique.  If you struggle with this recipe, give it some extra practice  Learning how to handle the dough gently and not over mix it, and keeping everything cold are key.  I keep my shortening in the freezer. Also, get a pastry cutter. It makes all the difference.

city:

text:
I came upon this recipe because I needed biscuits  for my gravy. I rarely have buttermilk on hand.  My first go with these, after reading NUMEROUS reviews and suggestions was a little try.  Before my 2nd try, I watched the video and did EXACTLY as they did.  BAM!  They came out perfect!  This time they accompanied fried chicken.  Do not be afraid. of these they are easy for a first timer, like me.  The dough will be sticky, but after kneading will be easy to work with and cut.  I have done it both using my cast iron skillet with dough sides touching and just placed on a cookies sheet and they rise beautifully.  I DID NOT chill my shortening, just pulled it out of the pantry but I did use COLD milk.   I hope my tips help someone else.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made them with butter instead of shortening and half and half. I mixed all of the dry ingredients with a whisk, trimmed the butter to very thin slices,  and used 3 ounces of butter. I used the whisk to stir it in until it looks clumpy, then I  added the half and half until it was a moist dough. I took it out of the bowl and put it on the counter. I pushed it down to about a 1/2 in thick, floured the top and folded and floured it about 10 times pushing it down every time. The Biscuits came out beautiful and taste  great!

We love these biscuits! Big, fluffy, moist but not dense. So I've made them many times but today was different. I had no butter but was determined to make a nice lunch for my son who came over to visit. I used olive oil and they came out great! Slightly different flavor of course. And while I  normally serve them with butter (yum) I served these with olive oil with Italian spices and garlic salt. I did NOT knead this batch but mixed it a lot and I did have to add extra flour as it was runny. Scooped it out  with a 1/3 cup measuring cup onto the baking sheet. They were great!

text:
These are the best biscuits ever, I would use buttermilk instead of regular milk, or decrease the amount of regular milk used in the recipe. I use a dough hook to blend milk and dry ingredients, and I only use 3/4 cup regular milk per 6 biscuits instead of the full cup. Always double the recipe, these keep well in a ziplock for weekday snacks.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been my go to recipe for biscuits for a few years now, once I discovered cooking from scratch was a way more enjoyable time in the kitchen. I always make a batch and a half.
  After making these, more times than I can remember, my only changes have been two things; I've started using bread flour and I really limit the kneading...I plop the dough  out onto a floured counter, give it about 5 "shmoosh and folds" (baking lingo!) and start cutting biscuits. I get about 12 to 14 fluffy, high rise biscuits...plus, with the end pieces I make an abstract, goofy biscuit for my granddaughter :)

Hope this helps...great recipe. Thanks!

text:
My go to biscuit recipe. Absolutely delicious. Every time I make them everyone raves and there isnt a single biscuit left. The key is to not over handle the dough. Just cut in the butter, mix the milk in until everything is wet, dump out on the counter, pat down and cut out whatever shape you want (Ive done them all) and bake. Dont over bak either. I love adding in seasoning a like basil or adding shredded cheese. I also love making these to top my vegetable melody.

text:
I've made these dozens of times and they always come out great.  Sometimes in a humid climate I have to add significantly less milk (think half), so be sure to add it gradually and stop when it starts to get sticky. I always get 6 biscuits - don't go smaller in order to get more! The best part about them is that they're big and thick.

text:
I made these and they were pretty flat, then I realized that there is no acid in the recipe to activate the baking powder.  (Usually buttermilk is the acid, but milk doesnt have enough acid.). I added just a pinch of cream of tartar and they rose beautifully.  So this is my new biscuit recipe with just that little addition.  Or you could use beer like one cook did, also with great results.

Display Name:
LTcooks

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My go-to biscuit recipe.  Super easy and PERFECT biscuits every time.  A couple of tips.  Don't over roll the dough.  Use a light hand and cut the biscuits thick.  Roll consistently to avoid misshapen humps and nodules, but don't press down too much.  Also, use parchment paper on the baking pan.  Parchment has magical properties.  I will give the bottoms a nice golden color, without it scorching.  I've made these with and without parchment and the results are vastly better with parchment.  Finally, don't let too many people know once you've perfected this recipe.  Old and young alike will beg you to make these over and over....
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I loved this Recipe. After reading the reviews I decided to make two batches. The first batch I made according to the instructions and they were great but had a bitter after taste. The second batch I lowered the baking powder increasted the sugar and used buttermilk. OMG! What fantastic biscuits. One person was correct with their coment on using a biscuit cutter, the sharp edge helps. What ever you do Dont over work your dough. I Only knew omg dough two times( just enough to get it covered in flour and a ball shape) I will keep this Recipe for some time . Love it.

text:
First off, THANK YOU to the reviewer who so kindly pointed out that over working the dough creates more gluten, rendering the end product hard. With that in mind, I followed the recipe except for substituting butter for shortening. This is the first time I've tried to make homemade biscuits, after a number of attempts, that resulted in fluffy, delicious biscuits! We live at around 2000 ft., so I adjusted my baking temp (decreasing by 10 degrees), and baked for 13 minutes. The tops of the biscuits did not come out golden brown, like the ones in the recipe's picture, but they were still very good. I'm really happy to have finally made edible biscuits!!

text:
I originally thought this recipe was for buttermilk biscuits and got all the way through it before I realized my mistake. I added 1 cup of buttermilk instead of regular milk and added 1/2 tsp of baking soda. The dough seemed a little wet when I rolled it out. The biscuits did not rise much at all but they tasted amazing. Ill tweak this recipe a little bit more.

I don't know if anyone else experienced this, but when I added the milk, I got batter, not dough. I double checked...made sure I have 2 cups of flour and hadn't missed anything else. So, I added another cup of flour; three total. From there, everything went fine. I did not knead my dough, though. Everything I've ever read about biscuit making says to just do enough to bring the dough together.

Fast and easy. Needed a non-yeast recipe because we were in a hurry.  These fluffed up and were tender and flaky.  I rolled them out like puff pastry dough. text:
New update: 1/16/19
I was kneading them like I do bread dough. I watched a video today and learned how to knead biscuit dough. they turned out really good and flaky. Someone told me to keep the dough as cold as possible so I mixed the dry ingredients together then placed them in the freezer for 15 minutes.  I use butter instead of shortening. I always bake them in cast-iron. I pre-heat the skillet then i place butter in the bottom, I place the biscuits upside down in the butter then flip them over to bake. The bottoms come out nice and brown, crisp with a nice butter flavor. 

Update 12/24/2018
I made these biscuits today. I didn't have any shortening so I used butter. Another recipe said to pat them out and then fold it three times like a letter then repeat 7 times. I did that with these and they turned out great. I used a big glass to cut them out so I only got 5 of them. They turned out big and tasty. 

I was hungry for pigs in a blanket so I searched for a good biscuit recipe. I found this one so I made half a batch and that was just right for five hot dogs. My main problem was it's pushing 100 degrees outside so I was not about to turn the oven on.  I saw on a Facebook group someone backed bread on the BBQ grill so I figured why not. I preheated my cast iron skillet on the stove for a couple minutes and then placed them on it. I don't have a thermometer on the grill so I have no idea how hot it was but it was hot since they finished in 16 minutes. I turned the skillet 18

My first review after years of membership! The Biscuits ROCK!
I followed the directions to the letter and was left with a sticky mess. I decided to add more flour and stir until I could atleast knead the dough. Cut them too thin their first time around, so had so knead it back together,  second time...success!
I had no hope they would turn out but put them in the oven anyway, they were 3 inches thick and VERY tasty!!! I went a ahead and made my gravy! (I was waiting to see how the biscuits turned out, otherwise I was going another route with the sausage) I am mixing the night before to see if they do get taller! Thx for my new biscuit recipe!

text:
I have made these several times now. I substitute half the shortening with butter.  I also bake mine in a cast iron skillet put very close together which causes them to rise higher. I make these about an hour before baking and let them set which also causes them to rise even further. Be sure to grease the bottom of your skillet and I use bacon grease for that. Yes, I do. They come out tall, flakey, tender and delicious.

text:
I have been testing and retesting biscuit recipes for about 2 years to find the one I could recreate most frequently in my climate. These are those. I don't have to keep buttermilk in the fridge either which is nice since biscuits are the only thing I use that for. This recipe is easy, fast, and you probably have everything you need for it already on hand. I keep my Crisco in the freezer which might help. Highly recommend lightly broiling them to turn them golden brown when the baking time is up BUT don't walk away. Nothing sadder than a burnt biscuit.

16719527
Display Name:
Mike
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6740215.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Achieving the perfect southern style biscuit can be elusive. This is a great recipe. However, mastering biscuit making technique is also an important ingredient. I agree with Discobunny; the buttermilk powder/ice cold water substitute for milk improves it a bit, but it's still very good using the original recipe. 

A few well-intentioned tips: Light kneeding is essential. Do not over-handle this dough. It should be somewhat wet/sticky when you turn it out and should  stay that way.  A light dusting of flour as you kneed will help you handle it. Please do yourself a favor and learn how to kneed biscuit dough and this recipe will work. It's not like kneeding bread dough. Also, practice.  

Next, I used lard and bread flour and the biscuits were especially soft and held together well (good if you're making biscuit sandwiches) and didn't crumble to the touch. Solid Crisco shortening also works well, as well as varying combinations of vegetable shortening and butter. Try grating frozen butter  or lard and you'll get great results.  

I also suggest that you weigh your flower instead of volume measuring it. You get much more accurate and consistent results.  2 cups of all purpose flour =
8.5 ounces or 240 grams.  Same weight for bread flour.  I hope these tips help.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-01-22T13:38:52.293
helpfulCount:

country:
None
text:
Great biscuits.  It is important that you only handle the flour enough to get things mixed.  Instead of kneading, I recommend folding in thirds and patting them out three times.  Also, the brand of flour you use is important.  I only use Dixie Lily or Pillsberry for biscuits.  They are very low gluten flours and make great busicuits.  I also HIGHLY recommend you use a scale to weigh your flour (4.5 ounces a cup for a total of 9 ounces flour)..  It makes all the difference in consistency when baking.

text:
These biscuits are INCREDIBLE!!!  I didn't quite need the whole cup of milk but that could be different the next  I make them.  Just add the milk a bit at a time.  Do not handle the dough too much.  I turned the dough out onto parchment paper and made folds in the dough using the parchment paper, rotating parchment paper 14 turns/kneads and dusted the dough lightly when needed.  Clear as mud?  Learned that technique from a King Arthur Flour Co. YouTube video.  

Next time I'm going to try substituting beer for milk and butter for Crisco!

text:
Love this recipe! I used butter instead of shortening because I prefer it. I cut up the butter into half inch squares and folded into dough. I did mix until combined and skipped the kneading as recommended in other reviews. In my experiences, kneading is not a good thing when it comes to biscuits. These are dense, buttery and perfect for smothering in gravy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These biscuits are PERFECT, great flavor and texture. This is the only biscuit recipe for me. I make it as  written except I use butter instead of shortening. A few tips to help make sure yours turn out perfectly every time ... WEIGH your flour. If you're just scooping you really have no idea how much flour you're getting and it's often too much.  If you're using butter (my favorite) freeze it first, then GRATE it into the flour. Do NOT dump the whole cup of milk in at once, start with about 2/3 c and only add more if needed. You may not need a full cup and too much liquid makes them dense. Make sure your baking powder is FRESH, it loses its freshness quickly so you need to replace it every 6 -12 months. Enjoy!

text:
I avoid baking at all costs, excluding box mixes. But, since I had a great sausage gravy recipe I bit the bullet with homemade biscuits! These were great, buttery flavor and a nice crumb. They didn't rise much though. I grated very cold butter with a cheese grater and added the given amount of salt while using salted butter. I added an extra half cup of milk (tip, next time add all the milk and wait for a bit to let it all moisten). The dough was quite tacky but I just floured a cutting board generously and used a glass cup to cut out rounds. This is my go to biscuit recipe :)

GLUTEN FREE/FODMAP VERSION: made these using Bob's Red Mills ALL PURPOSE baking flour (2 cups plus 2 tsp Xanthan Gum). I used Lactose Free milk and reg butter (FODMAP diet allows). You can substitute flour-per-flour with the addition of Xanthan Gum, in most cases. Bob's flour has a chart to help you determine how much Xanthan Gum to add per cup based on what you are cooking.

text:
So the first time I made these, I followed the directions exactly, and though they tasted OK, they had a slight  taste of flour and baking powder. So the next time I put in two extra teaspoons of butter (I didn't use lard, I never have lard on hand)  and really worked that in. And instead of 1 cup of milk, I used maybe 1/3 to a 1/2  cup, just so that it comes together and isn't dry. Followed the directions after that, kneading 15 times. Baked for 15 minutes, and then took them out and gently brushed the tops with butter. They were PERFECT. Delicious!

Display Name:
Dar

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an AWESOME recipe!  I found it last night and made it this morning.  I've never been able to make good biscuits despite being a good baker.  I think all the tips provided by reviewers are what really helped me.   The trick is to handle the dough as little as possible and mix gently.  Treat it like pie dough.  I used butter instead of shortening, buttermilk instead of milk and 2 tbsp. of sugar instead of 1 tbsp.  Also I absolutely LOVED the trick the one reviewer noted, freezing the butter and then grating it.  If you have an electric grater, no need to freeze it, but the grating works so well and makes the cutting in process so much quicker and easier.  When adding the grated butter to the flour mixture, try to get the grated butter in there as singularly as possible, then fluff with a fork.  Then using a pastry cutter, cut in for just about a minute, then you're done with that step.  

These biscuits are SO tender, this is a keeper recipe!!!
Review:

5

text:
I've made this recipe so many times now. Flawless. Can I tell y'all something though? Mix some shredded cheddar (like a cup) into the batter, and just spoon out lumps onto the pan. Don't worry about kneading or rolling, life's too short. While those are  baking, whip up some melted butter+garlic+parsley, then brush that on top when the biscuits are done. You now have copycat cheddar bay biscuits, like Red Lobster.

I've made these biscuits several times but always ignored the part about kneading the dough; I've always treated my biscuits like pie crust and handled the dough as little as possible. And my biscuits always came out a little flat. Tonight I made them again and had one PERFECT biscuit out of the batch: perfectly risen with golden edges, splitting slightly in half straight out of the oven. It was the "reject" biscuit I'd made out of the dough scraps, which had been worked and rerolled. Can't wait to make these again following the recipe's instructions!

userID:
2986640
Display Name:
Morgan Shaw
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5360188.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love these biscuits, my husband says they taste better than anything you'd get in a restaurant. I do always substitute COLD unsalted butter for shortening due to personal preference. They rise up nice and fluffy and are deliciously buttery. They come together fast and easy. I cut them out with an old bar glass I have (sizes them just how we like!) since I don't have a biscuit cutter. Make sure you only add as much milk as you need, I've also used buttermilk in a pinch and they were great then too (I did have to add slightly more due to the thicker nature). DO NOT OVERMIX YOUR DOUGH, you will end up with dense, yucky biscuits. I have served them with sausage gravy but my husband's favorite is to have them as breakfast sandwiches with eggs, cheese and bacon or sausage patties.

text:
These are a big surprise for me.  I needed a scone recipe last minute and found these.  I whipped them together very quickly; didn't even have time for kneading and they came out fantastic.  We have a vegan in the family so I subsituted shortening for vegan butter and used non-dairy milk.  The consistency was very sticky and I didn't hold out much hope.  I just used a spoon to place a dollop of dough on the cookie sheet and missed out the whole rolling and cutting the dough and they still came out great.  The second time I grated orange rind and added that and plan on doing a number of variations.

text:
I loved this recipe! The only changes I made were substituting butter for shortening, using buttermilk instead of milk and reducing baking powder to 2tsp and adding 1/2 tsp of baking soda. I don't have a pastry cutter so I couldn't "cut" the butter into the dough. Instead I cubed it up and threw it in. It was still in chunks when I baked it but I think it made the bottoms and top nice and crispy. I love the flavor and texture of these. Will definitely make these again and again! 
*i made 9 smaller biscuits and baked for 14 minutes.

text:
This is the best biscuit recipe there is, in my opinion. For those who struggle to find a biscuit recipe, remember 2/3 of biscuit making is pure technique. Just practice it and be careful not to overwork the dough. It also really matters what ingredients to use. I only use Rumfield baking soda for my biscuits, because  it  doesn't  leave a baking soda aftertaste. I also use butter instead of shortning.

This biscuit recipe was good, but the key to really really good biscuits is to increase the baking powder from one Tablespoon to three Tablespoons and switch the milk to buttermilk.  I have been making my biscuits like this for years and make them the night before and let them rise at room temperature the next day before sticking them in the oven will definitely get you the big talk about biscuits that you want.

Very buttery, delicious biscuits, but they were a bit on the denser side.  This biscuit is seriously addicting, and it uses less than the one stick of butter usually used.  The bottoms were a bit dark, but not burned. It's a keeper!  
Tip: One cup of milk may seem like a lot, and when I turned it out it was very, very sticky, but just make sure it's on a well floured surface.   For browning, make sure you turn the pan around halfway through.

text:
First off, I have made these a good 25+ times so I speak from experience when I say that these are a great recipe that results in great biscuits, it is fairly simple, but I would suggest you get biscuits cutters and a pastry knife. A pastry knife makes cutting in the butter/shortening easier. I use butter instead of shortening (butter creates a flakey biscuit with more layers) but shortening works perfectly fine. I have had almost no problems with this straight forward recipe and I would definitely recommend that you make these lovely biscuits.

userID:
17635586
Display Name:
Benjamin Valdez
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3332081.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will be certainly making these again, but there are a couple things that need to be changed. First, when I made them the first time, one cup of milk was too much and made it into hard drop biscuits. So I highly recommend you put 3/4 of milk. I also realized that the hotter the stove is the better they come out.(around 400-420) but don't leave them in too long, because then they will become hard. I also added about 1/3 of butter along with 1/3 of shortening. butter gives them better consistency as well as better taste. I also suggest put an egg wash( brushing a beaten egg over the top) as it keeps moisture and keeps then fluffy. Once again make sure you put 3/4 of milk! if you do these simple tips, they will be five star biscuits! loved them!

These biscuits always turn out great for me. I substitute butter for the shortening, otherwise i keep it the same! I also find using whole wheat flour makes them really hard and they dont rise very much, so i use either half whole wheat and half unbleached all purpose flour or all all purpose. they have a better texture and better rise.

text:
This is a really good biscuit recipe, but it takes some experimenting to get them where you want them. Our flour is heavier than flour in the US so I have to use more baking powder to get proper lift. I also have to double the recipe if I want to end up with 8 large biscuits. Make sure you dont overwork the dough.

My husband LOVES biscuits and he says these are the best he's ever had! I let the dough sit in the fridge overnight and did not knead as other reviewers recommended. I used butter instead of shortening and brushed the tops with butter and garlic after removing from the oven. I don't own biscuit cutters and used a glass instead. I did re-form the dough for the last two biscuits and while they weren't as pretty, they still rose and tasted delightful! Thank you for this recipe! I'm excited to freeze a batch to bake as needed!

userID:
14415290
Display Name:
Chad Gustafson
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1526488.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, I've been making this recipe for about 10 years now about twice a month... because it's good.  I've also made small changes a lot, just to see what would happen.  I won't bore you with all of them, but if I may, a few pointers.
1.  Use lard.  Not crisco, not anything other than lard.   
2. Grate the lard frozen or very, very cold and measure, 62g is just right for the recipe.  And put it in the freezer until ready to mix.
3.  Use AP flour if you have to, but if you have anything lighter use it, not cake flour, but the point is that you want not a ton of gluten, they're biscuits, not bread.  
4.  Use only as much milk as you need to get the mixture to not have any dry bits on the bottom of the bowl.  I've made them mostly by hand, but lately been using my Ankarsrum Assistent with good results.  The milk needs to be COLD and if you'd like, use buttermilk. 
5.  Once the lumpy goodness has been achieved and it forms a wet mass that you can get out of the bowl.  Do so and with a liberal amount of flour pat down to about 3/4".  Fold once horizontally, and then vertically and once more if you can.  Then pat down till about 3/4" again. 6.  Thou Shalt Not Twist the Cutter.

text:
This is the best biscuit recipe ever. The first time I made them I followed the recipe exactly. The second time I left out the sugar and they still were awesome. I also used butter instead of shortening because shortening is horribly bad for you. Then I began making them with whole wheat flour and the are still super fluffy. My daughters love them at breakfast some times they won't eat anything else so I began replacing 1/4 cup flour for 1/4 cup protein powder and still they are super fluffy. Some times before I add the milk I will add 1/2cup of shredded cheese and they still come out fluffy. I have also added garlic salt to pair with pasta dishes. This is definitely the best biscuit ever.

Display Name:
kathyd

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these biscuits many times and we've always liked them but I never thought they came out quite as big as advertised. This time I made the biscuit batter, turned it out on a floured board and folded over in thirds, like a business letter, pulling in all the loose bits as I went. I did this about three or four times, changing the direction of the fold each time  and then patted it out into a rectangle, wrapped it in cling wrap and put it in the frig for about 3-4 hours. When it came time to bake them, I cut the biscuits into 6 pieces using a sharp knife. I don't like to use a round cutter because you end up with scraps and when you roll or shape them they bake up very tough. This way there's no waste and you get 6 very tender biscuits. These baked up bigger than ever and were the best I've ever made. I think letting them rest before baking let the baking powder really react with the other ingredients. Also, I always use buttermilk when I make biscuits and I use half butter and half lard that I render myself (not the stuff you buy in the grocery store).

text:
I followed discobunny's tips and substituted butter for shortening, 2 tsp baking powder for the 1 tbsp. and added 1/2 tsp. baking soda.  I thought I was a good cook, but I had no idea what "Buttermilk Powder"  was.  I immediately googled it, ordered some and 2 days later, I was making these biscuits. They are absolutely delicious!  Crisp on the outside and tender and moist on the inside.  (I did brush with melted butter before and after baking.) The only thing I had a problem with was following the advice not to knead the dough.  I used the full amount of liquid and my dough was VERY moist.  I mixed it until it was just blended and had a huge problem patting it out and cutting out the biscuits.  Any tips on how to not over mix, but to get the dough to not turn out too sticky?  Should I cut back on the liquid or just combine the ingredients a little more?  A tip...You mix the buttermilk powder into the dry ingredients, then add the water separately.

Display Name:
Char

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very easy recipe and the biscuits were flaky and moist. I substituted butter (1/2 c frozen, then shredded into dry mixture) because I don't use shortening and I really like the buttery taste the butter gave to the biscuits. Oh! I almost forgot, I ran out of milk, so I had to substitute 1/2 c half and half (closest thing to milk I had in the frig). Yummy! Lastly, to save dough and not make them tough by too much kneading, I kneaded only about 10 times, rolled out to 1/2 thickness, and cut with a pizza cutter into squares. I then reshaped the squares into rounds. I made 2 for breakfast and froze the rest to see how well they thaw and bake later. I would definitely recommend this recipe to anyone who loves a good old-fashioned tasting biscuit.

text:
This is my go-to biscuit recipe, my husband always asks for it! I changed a few things:
*butter instead of shortening
*don't overmix it! (once the ingredients are combined, only knead a couple times or they will turn out tough.)
I do bake them for the full 15 min, but I brush them with melted butter about halfway through and they turn out super soft.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1883590.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I like LARGE biscuits that tower high. There is no way a two cup recipe will ever give me enough biscuits, so the first thing I did was double it. I also used butter milk for better flavor,  and used both shortening and butter. I love the results I achieve i.e.  tenderness and lightness of the biscuit when using  shortening,  and also using the butter  for added flavor.  Another tip you might appreciate is; before adding the milk or butter milk, I put my biscuit mixture into the freezer to make everything as cold as possible. Even my butter milk is in the freezer for 15-30 minutes before I incorporate the milk product into the biscuit flour mixture. This way, the butter and shortening will remain in it's solid state while I work and form the dough for cutting.  I yield 10 biscuits with the cutter I was using, doubling the recipe.

userID:
16541895
Display Name:
mediocrecook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have any shortening on hand and used 1/3 cup of coconut oil ( non-hydrogenated but refined) instead. I also added a pat of butter when cutting the coconut oil with the dry ingredients. I placed my biscuits on an un-greased cookie sheet covered with foil and put them in the refrigerator overnight. The next morning, I cooked them according to directions and they tasted wonderful! They weren't the biggest, fluffiest biscuits I've ever had but probably the best tasting biscuits I've ever made with such a simple recipe. We will be having these on a regular basis. Thanks for a great recipe.

A couple of tips: Mix the fats very well with the dry ingredients before adding milk. The wisk works wonderful for this. Also, avoid "over-kneeding" the dough. I didn't kneed my dough 15-20 times as the recipe suggested. You don't want to overwork your biscuit dough, just enough to get it together.

5

I love this recipie ..the changes I made are as follows. Per suggestions from others.  (1) don't knead the dough (2) turn out dough and pat to desired thickness(3) don't twist and cut(4)baked in cast iron skillet(4)melted butter and added garlic powder for more taste. (5)baked at  450 for 11-13 minutes. They turned out great !!

text:
These are awesome!  Used room temperature butter flavored shortening and all the milk.  Placed a thick layer of flour down to knead them...gently.  This isn't yeast bread you're making here people, they're biscuits.  You are creating layers in the dough so they raise higher, not trying to mix it.  Brushed the tops with milk before baking.  Perfect!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2415881.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best biscuit recipe of all time!  Made it exactly as it is written, but only cooked for 11 min.  I have a brand new oven and I think it is a little hotter or something, so watch them!  Over the past 9 years of my marriage I have tried NUMEROUS biscuit recipes and seriously my husband came in and thought they were those Frozen Pillsbury biscuits (His favorite).  They were so fluffy and had LAYERS.  I probably didn't pat them out thick enough because I made 11 biscuits not 6, (Probably why they didn't take as long to cook) but still awesome.  So much better than refrigerator biscuits!  Can't say anything bad about this recipe really.  Do NOT use a ROLLING PIN on biscuit dough- I have learned that from reading many recipes, just use your hands to pat the dough out.  Also be sure you are using a fork or even better a pastry blender to add the shortening.  Seriously- best biscuits ever!  Another tip-- don't wiggle your biscuit cutter around too much, should just be more like a stamp into the dough.

awifeyforlifey

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fabulous. I brushed the tops with butter as soon as they came out of the oven, and they were delicious. They took slightly longer to bake in my oven (everything does), but they were done in 20 minutes. I cut twelve biscuits instead of six, and they still rose fine. If you only made a half dozen they would rise HUGE (not a bad thing!). :)

You don't want to knead this dough like you would bread dough. I just pat mine down into a 1" round and cut out the biscuits. The more you handle biscuit or pastry dough, the denser and grosser it gets when it bakes. If you try to knead it, you'll end up with hockey pucks. Happy baking!

LACTOSE FREE VERSION!!! my daughter is lactoce free and so we made this recipe as is and only traded the butter for Coconut oil and then traded the milk for coconut milk. THEY WERE AMAZING!!! they had a little coconut flavour to them but we all loved it!! We used full fat coconut milk and had I did add a little more than what milk was called for but I dont think it was neessary. Also we baked ours in a muffin pan and used liners so they were like muffin biscuits. Simply droped the dough the liners with a spoon so it was super easy and mess free.

None
text:
This recipe was seriously so easy and and results were fantastic! Few tips - go slow with the milk. Better to have to add more than to add too much and the dough be ruined. Don't over work the dough. And i did a combo of cold butter and shortening. With more butter than shortening.  In my opinion, it helped make for a tender and flaky biscuit. :)

text:
These biscuits are sky high and perfect.  You have to be able to cut in the butter or shortening properly for them to turn out.  Also a metal cookie cutter, I started out using a glass cup but if you use a sharp metal cutter it makes sure the edges don't compress and allows the biscuit to raise more in the oven.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2169404.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe yields wonderful and light biscuits! 

I made these biscuits by hand (i.e. without use of a food processor). I made two small modifications: 
Butter instead of shortening 
Liquid - mostly 2% milk with a splash of heavy cream (both were on hand) and a splash of lemon juice (as a buttermilk substitute). 

Other methods included placing the butter chips, flour, and mixing bowl in the freezer until very cold. I also briefly placed the milk in the freezer for an extra chill. I stirred in the milk with a spoon and then kneaded minimally (estimate 2-4 times). I cut the biscuit with a glass, but made sure NOT to twist.

These are the best biscuits I've ever had. I'd only made biscuits once before, and wasn't thrilled with the results (though they turned out like the picture, and were OK). Baking is not a strong skill for me.  This was the first time I made them, and they came out light and tasty.  I only had skim milk in the house, but I always have plain non-fat Greek yogurt, so I whisked  about 1/4 cup of that in with the skim milk (I wanted to give the milk a little more depth).  And the biscuits were delicious! When I make them next time, I just might put rosemary in them for a little more flavor.  I will definitely keep making these.

text:
After reading the comments, I decided to add onion powder, garlic powder and a bit of grated cheese - delicious! Next time i will try sauting onion and garlic and adding it. One thing to remember when making biscuits - DO NOT twist the biscuit cutter back and forth as it prevents the biscuits from rising as much as they would if you just press the cutter into the dough and slightly move the cutter.

I really like making these but sometimes they come out a little to sticky but a little more flour and you are good to go. Biggest tip is to not roll them to flat for fluffy biscuits and don't knead the dough to much just a tiny bit like maybe 2-4 times is all it takes. These were made with the help of my 5 years old and he says they are the best:)

text:
I don't have any shortening so I used butter and they turned out fine. I added sharp cheddar cheese to the mixture at the flour step before I added milk. I use extra extra cold butter out of the freezer and grate it in with a cheese grater and then i try not to warm the dough up too much before i put them in the oven. They rise higher with cold dough and hot oven.

text:
absolutely the best Biscuit recipe of all. Easy, can't mess it up, lightly crispy on the outside and moist soft on the inside. I've tried the soda & sour cream recipe but it doesn't compare to these. If yours don't com e out right Use AP flour, Crisco shortening, and new baking powder. These are usually the reasons biscuits don't come out correctly. I've tried over 20 recipes and this is best. I'm always looking for better but I don't think this will be beat. "DON"T OVER BAKE"!!!12-13 minutes.

userID:
4778433
Display Name:
kelly blake
isPro:

5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2417115.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first recipe I have felt compelled to rate in all my years on allrecipes.   Fabulous recipe.  The key to biscuits is to handle them as little as possible,  as other have said.  Also, make a well in the center and add half of the milk, then add half of what's left.  You want to err on the side of too dry vs too moist.  Finally,  add the rest.  I think I used slightly under the cup and mine tuned out amazing!  Oh, don't use a hand mixer either.  Take a fork and knife and cut the shortening in until the mix is crumbly before adding the milk.

text:
I have been remiss in rating this recipe. These are the very best biscuits ever, and they are the ONLY ones I make. I have tried others, but always come back to this recipe. I don't use a cutter or glass to form the biscuits though. I just use a knife and cut them into squares - saves time, don't have to re-roll to use up the dough, and doesn't effect the final biscuit. Thanks J. P.

country:
None
text:
I was craving biscuits like crazy. Unfortunately, these delicious little buggers only threw more gasoline in the fire. I followed the recipe exactly except for I used half butter and half pumpkin puree instead of shortening and skim milk with a tablespoon of vinegar instead of regular milk. Proportionally it was all the same, though, and I was shocked (pleasantly so) at how buttery they tasted. This was my first time making biscuits, and I do think I overworked them a bit. One of these days I'll make them again and try to be more gentle, and maybe use sweet potato or applesauce instead of pumpkin puree. If they are as good as they are with the puree, I can only imagine how good they are with all butter.

text:
This recipe is perfect for the novice to the master baker! I, too, had to put a twist on mine by substituting frozen butter shredded with cheese grater and adding three ingredients. I included a tbls of black pepper, 1 finely chopped/seeded fresh jalepeno as well as handful of shredded cheddar. 
Made these for breakfast and was hoping to have at lunch with chili, did have to make a second batch for lunch!, no left overs after breakfast. 
Like so many others press down don't twist when cutting. 
BTW hamburger chain restaurant here in Texas trying make similar biscuits, hah!!! They should stick to hamburgers!!

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe 10 times now and every time they are perfect! Sometimes I use almond milk and sometimes cow milk and either work just fine. I think the trick is to not over-knead them. I mix in the milk until it is incorporated and that's it. Then I let it sit for a few minutes (it seems to make them rise better), and just drop little balls on a cookie sheet (it's faster than rolling them out). These freeze very well too. We just love love love these biscuits!!!

userID:
13536209
Display Name:
Steven L
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
21
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great biscuit recipe.  The only comment I would make is regarding the video on how to make these.  I don't think you should knead biscuit dough at all. Like pie pastry, kneading will make them heavier and less flaky. Simply gather the dough and press together firmly before rolling out.

Also, If you have opened baking powder in your cabinet that is older than 4 months, throw it out and buy some fresh.  If your biscuits are not rising as much as they should, stale baking powder is usually why. 

I have experimented adding some additional things to this basic recipe.  Try adding a little grated cheese, or some roasted garlic, or perhaps some diced sun-dried tomatoes just before adding the milk.  Also, I find they come out a little nicer flavored if you use buttermilk instead of regular milk, but they are delicious either way.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-06-21T18:42:13.817
helpfulCount:
0

None
text:
Similar to my biscuits but I use buttermilk and self rising flour. Do not knead the dough much at all or they will be tough. Use just enough milk so it will stick together, that way you won't need to knead much. Pour milk in a little at a time until you get consistency the way you need it.

text:
Excellent biscuits. I used 1 stick (1/2 cup) butter because I don't buy shortening. I also added 1tbs. lemon juice to my milk, for a buttermilk tang. I always let the dough sit in the fridge for a few hours before baking and make sure to handle the dough as little as possible. I also grate the cold butter into the flour mixture instead of cutting it, this gives it a yummy crumbly result. Thanks for the recipe :-)

text:
Great biscuits! I've made them multiple times, and I always have great results. The last time I made them, I added some diced thick-cut bacon and fresh sage. After pan frying the bacon and sage, I let them cool, mixed them into the dry mix after cutting in the butter, then added the milk and continued from there. I thought they might be too salty with the full tsp of salt plus the bacon, so I cut it back to 1/2 tsp. I will use 3/4 tsp next time. After they came out of the oven, I brushed on a little  bacon fat. Delicious!

I really wanted to make biscuits since I never had before and this Thanksgiving I am in charge of rolls and biscuits at my Wife's Grandmothers house.  SO I needed some practice.  I used cake/pastry flour and home made butter instead of shortening.  Also, I didn't have a circular cutter so I just cut the dough into squares using an 8" chef's knife.  Also, I believe that I over worked the dough which kept the biscuits from raising as much as I had hoped. 
The biscuits themselves tasted great.  My kids loved them with honey and I thought they were perfect all by themselves.  5 stars for an easy and delicious recipe.

Display Name:
Kathy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/154.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This biscuit recipe is good, and made nice big moist biscuits.  They were slightly bitter or salty, so next time I may add a little less salt, but overall they were great.

I blended the dry ingredients first, and then added the shortening, and blended it together with my fingers and then added the milk.

The secret to fluffy biscuits is to work the dough as little as possible, so as soon as everything was moistened, I patted the dough out on a lightly floured board, and cut with a biscuit cutter.  

I sprayed the baking pan with cooking spray, but if I'm cooking bacon, my grandpa- who's from the South always told me when I make biscuits, to put a little bacon grease in the pan and to lay the biscuits in the pan and turn them over so both sides have a coating of bacon grease. 

I used these biscuits to make ham egg and cheese biscuits, and they turned out great!  Thanks for posting the recipe!

text:
Love this recipe! Biscuits always turn out thick and fluffy. 

We use butter instead of shortening, and usually wind up using closer to 3/4 cup of milk than a full cup, or it gets sticky. I just mix the dough until all the flour is mixed in uniformly, and knead hardly at all. 

I've made them with up to 1/3 whole wheat flour and had them still turn out great.

These biscuits were the best. I have tried several recipes and box mixes. These were ABSOLUTELY DELISH, AND SO LIGHT AND FLUFFY!!!, Very easy to make. I did take advice from some of the other reviewers and put the dough in the fridge for a while. It worked out well, cuz it was gonna be a while b4 dinner and I just made the dough ahead of time. I did cut some of the shortening with Smart Balance and used mostly skim milk(thats just what we keep in the house)and happen to have a little buttermilk, oh and I didn't knead it too much also. OMG!!! My son was in Heaven, some jelly and butter, whoowee. This is definitely in the rotation. Thanks J.P.

text:
These turned out excellent! I have tried dozens of recipes and I could never get them to rise or taste the way I wanted. My initial thought was to avoid kneading them but I decided to stick to the recipe. They were not tough at all. I got so excited when I opened the oven to check them and they had risen so high! I even cut them out with a glass which is supposed to "crimp" the edges and hinder the rising. I did pour the whole cup of milk in and then had to add about 1/4 cup more flour. I'm going to try using butter next time instead of the shortening. Excellent!

None
text:
Great biscuits! I made 3 batches. The first batch was very good and it was made as written.  The second batch came out fantastic!  I replaced the milk with buttermilk, the shortening with butter, and the TBS of baking powder with 2 teaspoons of baking powder and 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda.  I sifted all the dry ingredients and placed them in my food processor.  I added the butter (I cut them up into little pats) and processed for a minute until they resembled coarse crumbs.  I then slowly added the milk until it was starting to form a ball and then dumped it on to my flour covered counter.  Yummy! These were so good and will be my biscuit recipe from now on :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just got through making these biscuits. Like some others, I used 2-tsp baking powder and 1 tsp baking soda, and I subbed butter for shortening, as well as the buttermilk powder, but used 2% milk instead of water. I also added 4-T cheddar cheese powder, 1-T of garlic powder, and 1-T minced garlic, and a cup of shredded Mexican blend cheese. When I cut in the butter, I didn't think the amount of butter called for was enough for the flour mixture, but did not increase it this time. It did take a bit more milk than called for. I just patted out the dough and cut the biscuits without kneading or rolling. It made 15 large biscuits. I then put them in the fridge on a cookie sheet for about 6 hourss to let the flavors of cheese and garlic to meld, then baked for dinner. OMG! These were sooo good! I warn you, if you follow my changes, you can really taste the garlic, but we loved them! I didn't think they rose to be any bigger than any other biscuits though.

b_t_01

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe comes out perfect every time!  Make sure to cut in the shortening really well.  Stir the dough until it is just barely moistened, then turn it out onto a floured surface.  Knead only until it comes together a little more, then pat it out into a rectangle.  Skip the round biscuit cutter and use a large knife to cut into about 8 rectangles so you only have to cut ONCE.  If you use a round cutter, get them as close together as possible and don't re-roll scraps.  The key is to work the dough as little as possible!  Brush the tops with melted butter before and after baking and these babies will beat your favorite restaurant biscuits hands down!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I recently made biscuits from another recipe and they didn't rise.  So I bought new Baking Powder and used this recipe and wow were they amazing.  I made six really big biscuits and baked them for 15 min. at 425, and they could have baked a minute or two longer.  But I served them with gravey and they were yummy!!!  I also made the dough the night before and wrapped the dough in waxed paper and put in the frige. All I had to do was roll them out in the morning. I did knead the dough lightly just a few times before rolling it out. I used real butter and 2% milk. This is a great recipe and I'll be using it again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use this recipe for one thing and one thing only: chicken pot pie. Instead of a pie crust, I make a batch of these, cut them out, and place them on the pot pie. Baked altogether, it comes out delicious.
I find I can't knead this dough for 15 to 20 minutes, since I do it by hand. Instead, I knead for about 6 to 8 minutes, cut the dough into biscuit form and knead each biscuit in my hand for a few extra minutes. The warmth from my hand and the concentrated kneading seems to work very well. These come out big and tender every time.

text:
This is my go to biscuit recipe. They bake up nice and tall if I follow the suggested serving size but I don't mind squeezing in a few extra biscuits when I have extra guest over and they are still great! I lower my oven to 400 and cook for 15 minutes then I rub some butter on the tops while they are still hot.  One time I had a little extra dough that wouldn't quite make a full size biscuit so I rolled it out fairly thin, spread butter on, sprinkled with a generous amount of cinnamon and sugar and rolled it up. I cut it into 4 pieces and baked with my biscuits. They were great! Add some powdered sugar mixed with a touch of milk for a glaze and in no time I had both biscuits and iced cinnamon rolls, Yay me!

I love biscuits, but I'm terrible at making them. I always knead them too much. I was so focused on not over-kneading that I almost forgot the butter! I had to add it last, after the milk. I barely touched the dough after that. They turned out great! Light and flaky. I will make this over again for sure. Those who complain that these are bland, might try making them with butter, or at least half butter half shortening.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used sweetened vanilla almond milk, and they came out great! I used to add some sugar when I used dairy milk in biscuits, and sweetened soymilk or almond makes them just right.
I'd use plain soymilk, or add a teaspoon of lemon to sub for buttermilk, if wanting a savory one.
Dismiss all the bad reviews. This is the basic recipe-just look compare to all the others. The only difference would be in the amount of milk, and as this recipe states "Gradually stir in milk until dough pulls away from the side of the bowl." That means you don't have to use it all. Amounts for liquid will vary.
Just don't over work the dough, stir till just combined. If you let it set for a while, as others have mentioned, the baking powder will have longer to rise.

text:
These biscuits are good. They go together fast and with few ingredients. I always have to add a tad more flour to the mix so it's not quite as sticky. However, they rise beautifully and are soft and perfect for biscuits and gravy!  I don't roll out the dough. I just add some flour to the counter and then turn the dough a couple of times and pat down to the thickness I want. I then use a large mouth cup to cut mine out.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is simply THE best scone recipe and I love that it is so versatile! Moist and buttery, they don't irritate the roof of your mouth like the usual baking soda scones. This is the only recipe I use, and I just add whatever I like to change it up - right now, I'm using it to make delicious pumpkin scones! I have added sharp cheese and caraway, bacon and cheddar, and always have a batch of plain ones handy - they go wonderfully with chili and stews! And, yes, they are huge! To make them extra buttery and flaky, make sure not to cut the butter in too finely. YUM!

text:
Great biscuit recipe. I followed it exactly, but used cold butter instead of shortening. I don't think I used a full cup of milk either. This made 6 biscuits with scraps that probably would have made another, but I was too lazy to roll the dough back out. I would cut down the salt if you use salted butter. Delicious, tall and buttery biscuits!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe.  I thought maybe it was a little heavy on the baking powder just based on the taste, but I know that's tricky with biscuits 'cause you need lots of baking powder for them to rise up nice.  About the gal who was having trouble working with the sticky dough.  Good biscuit dough is always like that.  Put a dusting of flour on your counter.  Turn out the dough from the bowl onto the counter and dust the top of the dough with a bit more flour so you can touch it to flatten it out.  It just takes some practice.  It also might help to butter your fingers.  The less you handle the dough the better though!  Good luck.

Great biscuit recipe! I've tried several recipes that have disappointed, but this one is exactly what I'm looking for. I substituted margarine for the shortening, just added milk until the proper consistency (maybe 3/4 C.) and omitted the kneading-instead just patted the dough together. I definitely recommend brushing with melted butter. The biscuits turned out fluffy and perfect!

text:
Followed the directions in mixing the dough. After reading other reviews I did not have the intentions of  kneading the dough for 10-15 minutes, but the dough was way too sticky to roll out. So I kneaded the dough for a couple minutes then added a little bit of flour and rolled out the dough. My daughter was helping and I was not paying attention to the fact that she rolled the dough pretty thin so our biscuits were not very bit. They were more like small bite sized biscuits. I added a little bit of butter to the top when they came out of the oven. They were good, no one felt as though they were dry and tasteless. I will make this again and pay attention to size so they come out bigger, but overall these were good.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these multiple times now. I use butter instead of shortening, and only use about 3/4 cup milk (as other reviewers suggested). The trick is to only add just as much milk as you need. Once everything is mixed (but make sure not to overwork it!), I dump it onto a piece of parchment paper and gently shape into a rectangle about 1/2 inch thick.  I usually double the recipe and make about 9 super biscuits! Simple to make and easy to eat, what's not to love?

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone I've made these for has loved them; I've never had leftovers! I've also tried making them with buttermilk instead of milk or butter instead of sugar, and they're delicious both ways, it just depends on your flavor preference! Using butter instead of shortening to me does turn out a slightly crisper, more Southern flavored biscuit! I never knead the dough, just turn it out and use my hands to flatten it to the shape/thickness I want. I typically use a juice glass as my cutter though and get 12-13 good sized biscuits still from that method.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a pretty good recipe. I substituted homemade buttermilk for the milk(1TB vinegar +1 cup milk,sit for 10 mins.),substituted 3 TB butter + 3 TB shortening(for flavor and tender texture), used a "pinch" of sugar and did not knead dough "at all". I gently pat my dough into a circle then cut with cutter. I also brushed tops with melted butter before and after baking.They have an excellent rise, flavor and texture. I dion't like to waist "scraps" so I gently pushed them together into a rectangle and baked as well. Great taste with no waste. Made 7 "big" biscuits.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Even though I have been baking all my life, I've never made biscuits before.  My family has always used the canned refrigerated type but not only are they getting expensive, homemade is always healthier.  So with that said, I've tried these a few times now.  I like the food processor method recommended by another reviewer for the ease. I've substituted buttermilk for better flavor.  I found that not kneading produces a more tender biscuit than kneading.  I like making them ahead of time and refrigerating.  The last time I made them I added a garlic-herb cheese.  My only real problem with these is they take almost twice as long as the 13-15 min. baking time as stated in the recipe, maybe I'm making them too thick.  But I will be making these again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice recipe, thank you JP!! This is the first time I've made American Biscuits (I'm South African) and already they are on my favourite short list, with a few minor adjustments. 1 Tablespoon BP - I used 3 teaspoons. 1 Tablespoon sugar - I used 2 teaspoons. 1/3 cup shortening - I used 62g Holsum. Instead of cutting out rounds I shaped the dough into an oblong, and cut into 6 pieces with a knife, then popped them into greased muffin pans. (Don't flatten them - as the BP works they will fill up the spaces in the pan.) Brush with milk. 15 minutes baking and I had golden, crisp on the outside soft on the inside biscuits.  The less you handle the dough the lighter they  will be.  These are a cross between what we would call a scone and a bread roll. Hubby loved them with syrup!!

userID:
3794009
Display Name:
misscarolb

69

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/230327.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far my FAVORITE biscuit recipe! I think I've discovered the secret to making big flaky biscuits (besides starting with an amazing recipe). I saw this on the Food Network and it truly works! Here's what ya do...once you've mixed your dough and flopped it onto the counter (make sure your dough isn't too wet) begin to roll or flatten it out (I use my hands), dust the top with a little flour and fold it over itself, flatten again, dust with flour and fold...do this a few times and then flatten to your desired thickness and cut into biscuits. The folds provide even air pockets and you end up with a biscuit that pulls apart in flaky wonderful-ness :) Good luck!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been using this recipe for years! It is fail safe - as others have noted, the full cup of milk is not necessary just add until you have the right doughy consistency.  Sometimes I substitute buttermilk for milk, for a fluffy delectable flavor, or I sometimes add a cup of shredded sharp cheddar cheese for a variation, add to the dry ingredients before the milk.  Sometimes I add chopped roasted garlic for another variation.  A great biscuit all-around!

None
text:
Best biscuit recipe I've encountered thus far! I did make one small change...I substituted butter for the shortening. Tip: when you add butter, make sure it's cold...and grate it into your dry ingredients. When you grate the butter in, it mixes more thoroughly, giving you even fluffier biscuits!    This recipe also makes great herbed biscuits...just add 1 tbsp. of your favorite dried herb to the dry ingredients (I've used rosemary and an Italian blend) and...voila!

Display Name:
hi-desert Kath

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these biscuits several times. The first time exactly as written (and they were very good), then I made a few changes because that's just what I do. Cook's Illustrated suggests replacing part of the buttermilk with sour cream in their pancake recipe because, they say, modern , cultured, pastureized buttermilk is less flavorful than the real thing. Using that logic, I made this recipe tonight with 2/3 cup buttermilk and 1/3 cup sour cream. The taste was excellent. Next time I plan to also replace part of the shortening with butter and make them ahead of time as some others have done. I also fold just 3-4 times and pat into a square a little over an inch thick and cut into six biscuits with a sharp knife. I also slip them under the broiler the last minute or so to get a golden brown on top. Wonderful recipe John, thank you!

I've made these twice now - once following directions exactly except replacing all-purpose with whole wheat flour, and once with all the right ingredients but not kneading it. text:
This is a awsome recipe!! I have made them dozens of times and never had a problem with them. For christmas morning i made up this mix the night before except i didnt add the milk. I covered it with a damp towle overnight and in the morning i was able to just add milk , kneed and had fresh hot biscuits baking in no time at all. I  always double or triple my recipe cause they are a huge hit. I like to use butter flavored shorting and when they are done brush the top with butter but they are great without it.

Wow!  These are the most amazing biscuits I have ever made.  Replaced 1/2 cup of the white flour with whole wheat and lard instead of the shortening. I was worried about all of that milk and the soggy mess it made of the dough, but kneading it a little with more flour made it just right.  Popped them right into the oven and they skyrocketed!  A slice of butter and a generous spoon of preserves on these hot biscuits is divine.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/622464.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these tonight for the second time. They were fantastic! The first time I made them, they were a flop, but the second was amazing. I tried them first in a food processor, but that overdid it. The second time, i did it the way the barefoot contessa says: in my KitchenAid.  Put all the dry ingredients together in your mixer and give it a quick spin. Cut the butter into pieces and throw them in. Run the mixer on low, until the butter's broken up into pea sized pieces. Then, add the milk slowly until just combined. Then take it out and pat down on floured surface. You can fold it over once to get more out of it, but throw away the rest because it's too tough after that. Brush the tops with butter and a little salt and bake. IMPORTANT: make sure your oven's at the right temperature! That really does make all the difference.

text:
I was not impressed with this recipe, but I think it could be improved upon...it's a good base.  I followed it exactly for the first batch and the biscuits were rather flat and way too salty.  For the second batch I cut the salt to 1tsp., used margarine instead of shortening and didn't knead them or roll them out, just patted them to about 1.25 inch and then cut out.  I had better results with a small circle as far as rising goes.  These were nowhere near the Grands biscuits but I'll keep working with recipe to see if I can get there.  Thanks for a great base!

if there was a way of giving 10 stars, my husband would do just that to this recipe these are so good and yes they are big.the 2nd tme i turned mine into pizza dough  wow excellent pizza. but i did add finely chopped parsley to the dough at the very end just before turning onto floured surface then roll it out to desired thickness , you may not want to make it too thick as it is very filling, bake for about 5 minutes, remove from oven and top with yo favorite toppings, return to oven and bake until done maybe another 10 minutes. Will definitely be using this recipe as my pizza dough recipe since my husband doesnt eat yeast he was so happy to finally eat pizza after such a longtime. he ate about 3/4 of the whole pizza but we stil had leftovers after my 3yr old son and i had eaten our share

These biscuits are just like the ones my mom makes, that she learned from her mom!  The only problem with my mom's recipe is that there is no recipe- she did everything by "feel" and so I never knew how to make them.  I know that these biscuits have the same ingredients that she uses, but now I know how to make them! I did take another reviewers advice and use my food processor for mixing- it was incredibly easy and took only minutes to turn out homemade biscuits. No more canned biscuits for us!

I have never attempted to make biscuits, but this recipe looked so simple I couldn't resist.  Despite the fact that I added too much milk and patted mine down to 1/2 in instead of 1 in, the flavor was still great and they were light and fluffy on the inside!  I mixed just until the batter came together and then patted the dough out (no additional kneading).  I also subbed butter for shortening.  I served them hot out of the oven with "Fluffy Scrambled Eggs" from this site.  It was just like a Sunday morning breakfast out, only my husband and I were still in our pajamas!  I can't wait to try these biscuits again - next time with sausage and gravy!

text:
That's an amazing recipe. I followed every step and used butter instead of shortening. My kids just love them... fluffy and tasteful! In my country, biscuits are not popular but since I came back from US I can't live without them. I think the secret is not working much the batter. If you do knead it much...your biscuit will come out heavy and dense.

text:
I'm converted... WOW, these are good. I cut in cubed cold butter instead of shortening. I wasn't about to bother with freezing it and shaving it, and you don't need to either, they still turn out great. I went ahead and added the whole cup of milk at once and found it to be too much. After adding a little more flour the dough was beautiful to work with. I rolled it to 1 inch thick and use a cup to cut rounds. Baked them for 13 min. and they were HUGE, FLUFFY, YUMMY! I got 8 giant biscuits. I will never buy them from the can again...

text:
These were surprisingly fast to make and came out perfectly without having to worry about getting the measurements exact. The only precaution I took was making sure to not over-kneed since I have worked with other baked goods before, where the goal is to generate layers of air. They are every bit as good as the version from my favorite southern restaurant, Babe's Chicken House.

text:
Fabulous! I doubled the recipe and I didn't have the prep time available, so I threw all the dry ingredients in the Kitchen Aid mixer - mixed thoroughly. Next, I slowly added the shortening and lastly the milk. It was a little too wet, so I sprinkled in some flour while it was mixing. Then patted out the dough on a floured counter, used a smallish biscuit cutter and put them in the oven. They taste wonderful! Finally!- I don't have to go to the local diner to get the best biscuits in town!

None
country:
None
text:
Wow, this was super and it was better than I expected. It worked out real good just like KFC. I added margarine instead of shortening and added 1 tsp white vinegar to sour the milk and it was great! I also baked it on a pizza pan with holes to get a good texture on the bottom and so it wouldn't get too brown and hard on the bottom. It cooked evenly all over. I did also brush melted butter on the tops before baking and it just looked beautiful when it came out. This is the best recipe I have found and will keep it as a treasure. I will also use it as a base to make dumplings, shortcake, and cobblers. Thank You!!! And a job well done!

text:
This recipe says it may take you several attempts to get it just right - I think that's probably accurate.  Attempt #1 on 10/25/08 - I used butter instead of shortening b/c I love butter.  The dough is really, really sticky so you need a lot of flour to handle/roll it (at least much more than I used b/c the dough stuck all over the place).  I tried to handle the dough as little as possible after reading other's reviews.  These didn't turn out as well as I wanted them to, they were not big and they were dense, but not hard.  They had great flavor.  I definitely have a feeling my results will improve with repeated attempts!

Display Name:
Sarah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/148478.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These came out just okay. They did not rise into the huge biscuits I expected and they were dense instead of fluffy like I'd hoped for. I made them a day ahead of time, only kneaded the dough a couple times and patted into a little round before cutting. **Update: I tried these again and have bumped them from a 2 to 3 star. 15 to 20 times of kneading produces brick biscuits. This time, after incorporating the milk, I picked up a handful of dough (non-kneaded), formed it lightly like a hamburger patty and put it on the pan, letting the biscuit sides touch. This was the least dense biscuit I've made so far. I used half whole wheat flour/half all purpose flour, cold butter instead of shortening, and will use this forming method in the future.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first time I've made biscuits from scratch and these were definitely good.  They didn't live up to what I hoped for though, and mine definitely didn't look like the ones in the photos - all of that may be my lack of biscuit baking experience though.  I made mine using a food processor, and the dough came together very easily.  I patted the dough out, cut it and wrapped the biscuits in foil.  Then I refrigerated them overnight so we could have fresh baked biscuits for dinner the next night.  I was disappointed that they were pretty flat, not fluffy and tall like I had hoped for.  They were also a little crumbly so I'm thinking I probably either kneaded too much or not enough, though I'm not sure which.  I tried not to handle the dough anymore than I had to, so maybe I didn't knead it enough.  Also, we had leftovers and I thought they were better after they were reheated.

I'll keep trying, and update if I have better luck next time.

Display Name:
blackberrygrl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/48264.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe 5 stars despite my changes to the basic ingredients. I used what I had on hand and they still turned out great. What I changed? 1 1/2 cup all-purpose flour and 1/2 cup bread flour, 1/3 cup unsalted butter, and 1/3 cup buttermilk. Method? Used a fork to cut in butter to course. Required all milk to pull away from bowl. I liberally floured the counter folded over roughly 12 times, then rolled out to about 1/2" (I have a hard time judging). I baked for 15 minutes and they were a nice golden brown. I topped with melted butter. They were light and tender. Most rose nicely despite my overestimate of depth. Reaction? Family and I loved them! I'm keeping this recipe on hand.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent, simple, fluffy biscuit every time. I use it as the dough for my cinnamon buns and it is amazingly good...butter the bottom of a round cake pan, sprinkle in brown sugar and sliced almonds with a few drops of water. Make and roll out the biscuit dough as usual, then spread mixture of margarine, cinnamon and brown sugar about an inch from one long edge. Roll up jellyroll style, use a piece of thread to slice roll into buns and place into a loose ring around the edge of the buttered pan, last 2 in the middle. The buns will grow together in the oven. I frost them with cream cheese icing and they are always gone before I get a second one... Really yummy at brunch, not overly sweet and this biscuit dough holds the cinnamon butter remarkably well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The dough is definitely sticky as noted by other reviewers, but the biscuits come out great.  I added a little flour during the kneading stage, but not much.  Don't be tempted to pat your dough out thinner than 1", your biscuits will not be as fluffy.  Also, another reviewer had a great tip -- don't twist the cutter when you're cutting out the biscuits.  It seals the edges and they don't rise as well.  Kist press it down and lift it back off.  Another reviewer suggested cutting the dough with a sharp knife, which would seem to work well too.

text:
This was my first time making biscuits from scratch and these were wonderful! I took the advice of another reviewer and put everything in my food processor until I hit Step 3. I followed Step 3 as written in the recipe. I used buttermilk instead of milk and butter instead of shortening. I didn't really knead the dough and instead, formed it into a big square and used a knife to cut it into 6 squares. I left it in the oven for about 13 minutes and they fluffed up nicely. The outside is a bit crunchy but the inside is so soft. This reminds me of KFC biscuits. Yum!

text:
These are so good and easy.  I used stick "butter" flavor shortening that i had frozen.  Works so much better that way.  Cut it into the flour with a pastry cutter.  Make sure you dont roll them out too thin.  They dont puff much at all.  Brush with soft butter when right outta the oven.  So good with fresh strawberry jam or all natural grape jelly.  Heck good with anything slathered on it.  Great plain too.  Hubby "tested" like 3 right outta the oven.

text:
These are delish! I have tried several biscut recipes in the past, with lackluster results. These were super easy and SO good. One note - probably obvious, but I forgot so... - if you sub regular salted butter for the shortening, make sure you cut back on the salt, or your biscut will be salty. They'll still get gobbled up, but would be better with less salt. These will be featured at my house on a regular, I can guarentee that!

I've made these a few times now, and I've found the recipe calls for too much milk. However, I live in Japan and it's rainy season here now so the humidity may be having some affect on the batter. The last time I actually used just a bit more than 1/2 a cup of milk. Regardless, they rise wonderfully, look great and taste pretty good. They go well with jam or gravy, and don't last too long in our house!

text:
Easy recipe.  I used self-rising flour, and they rose up really high.  I used a food processor, which made it so easy to mix.  I needed less than 1 c. of milk, and I had to add about 1/4 cup extra flour b/c the batter was too sticky.  I used big heart shaped cookie cutters and they turned out really cute!

text:
These biscuits are absolutely fantastic.  They're a real treat for our family on Sunday mornings.  It does take a bit of trial and error to get them to be the right size, but so worth the effort.

I have made and loved the biscuits following the recipe exactly as written, and I have made the recipe substituting shortening with butter, and using buttermilk instead of sweet milk.  Our family has loved the recipe both ways.  (Though I myself tend to like the variation best.)

text:
These always turn out excellent.  The only time they didn't was when I added extra flour to get the dough less gooey.  I think it was just extra humid and they ended up tasting like pure flour.  I have learned to use the recipe exactly as stated.  If the dough is sticky I just drop them onto the cookie sheet instead of rolling.  Other than that these make restaurant quality biscuits that are perfect for jellies or sausage gravy.  Thanks J.P.!  This is a staple recipe in our house!

country:
None
text:
Mine turned out tender, flakey and wonderful.  I cut the recipe in half, added 1/8 teaspoon of garlic powder, 1/2 cup of cheddar, and used less milk than stated (somewhere between 1/3 to 1/2 cup for my scaled down recipe).  I kept the handling to a minimum and skipped the kneading.  I cut my dough with a knife into 4 wedges and baked on a pizza stone for maybe 20 minutes until I got the crispy golden crust that I like.

really great and super easy.  i used butter instead of shortening to omit the hydrogenation and they turned out sooo good.  i actually used them as pizza crust so i could make my son some lunch.  it turned out deeee-lectable.  much better than the store bought variety that have so much junk in them.  i was at a hotel last week that had awesome biscuits on their continental breakfast buffet and these have got to be the same recipe!  i did follow the suggestions from others and tried not to over handle them.  also, i feel like i had to add a little extra flour.

text:
I am a self-taught cook, so I have very few family recipes and have to search for the "perfect" recipe for all of the basics.  This is the closest to "perfect" biscuits that I've found!  They are super-easy to make, and taste great.  My only complaint was that I did notice the slight bitter aftertaste, but the taste of the biscuits themselves more than make up for it....the biscuits aren't bitter at all.  I did substitute unsalted butter for the shortening, since I like a buttery flavor to my biscuits.  I also noticed that a few people said they used baking soda instead of baking powder...I wonder if this makes a big difference in the finished product???  I highly recommend this recipe.  Yum!

text:
These were very good.  I used margarine & non fat milk, cut the recipe in half and baked them in my cheapie toaster oven.  I was careful about the amount of milk I used as suggested by other reviewers, but I could have used less I think because the biscuits were pretty heavy.  They raised wonderfully in the oven, but "deflated" a little when taken out.  But all in all very good.  Thanks for the recipe.

OH MY GOSH......These biscuits are quite honestly the BEST I have ever tasted!!! My little trick was to 'sift' all the ingredients and it made them really fluffy and light.(I used the Canadian Flour and I know that it is very different in texture from the American Flour)  There are so many variations you can do to enhance this YUMMY recipe!! text:
First try was tasty, but lacked "something". The second time, I didn't have enough milk. I used half cup evaporated milk and half cup whole milk. To get a better rise, I heated milk in microwave and dissolved one teaspoon of yeast. Do use a buttery shortening mixture.
*** Doing this, made the best biscuits ever !***

text:
I had some trouble with this recipe as the batter was very milky and I had to add some more flour to get it to a consistency which I could knead.  Next time I will add milk only until the dough pulls away from the side of the bowl - which is actually what the recipe states.  The biscuits turned out all right in spite of this.  If I had reviewed them right away I would have given them four stars, but they were so good the next day that I decided to give them five instead.

text:
Not sure if this will sound like a compliment or not.  But these reminded me of the biscuits that you get at KFC (which I love).  I followed the recipe almost exactly.  The only thing was that the dough was very sticky when it came time to knead it.  I ended up adding a good amount of flour during the kneading process.  They did turn out huge, next time I might try making 10 or 12 instead of six biscuits that are the size of my head.  Very tasty though, a good recipe (especially if you're low on ingredients like I was).

country:
None
text:
These were wonderful!  I have been wanting to try this recipe for a long time and last night made them to use with strawberry shortcake.  Yummy!!  I used crisco butter flavored shortening, which just added to their yummy flavor.  I barely got 6 biscuits from the dough (just right with the recipe) ~ the only thing that didn't quite match up is in the recipe it says to roll or pat dough to 1 inch thickness, which I think is wrong, I had my dough at 1/2 inch thickness and that made 6 biscuits perfectly.  Unless you use a smaller than normal biscuit cutter you will not be able to get 6 biscuits out of 1 inch thick dough.  Everyone loved these and I will most definetly make them again, thanks for the best biscuit recipe ever!!! :)

Easy, basic and satisfying biscuit recipe.  This time around, I used whole wheat flour for half the flour portion and half unsalted butter for the shortening portion.  Turned out great!  For an interresting variation, I cut the biscuits using heart shaped cookie cutters.

Easy as Bisquick, with 10 times the taste - I've bought my last can of biscuits!  I threw these together in about 15 minutes, substituted butter for the shortening, and made drop buscuits.  They were so delicious, we ate them plain!  I'd read quite a few reviews that stated they were bland, but my family would disagree.  I found they had a sweet buttery taste (maybe due to the substitution?) - truly addictive!  Thanks J.P.!

text:
This is a really great basic recipe for biscuits. I found that adding warm water instead of milk and not use a full cup works well when I don't have milk. I also add the juice from my minced garlic. Gives it a nice flavor and smooth texture. I have made many biscuits before and I think the trick to cooking them is to make sure you take them out early or else you will ruin them. You can always put undercooked ones back in :) Thumbs up J.P. Great recipe!
